for stealing, on the 11th of Sept., 1 sovereign, 1 crown, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Elisa
beth Benson.

ELIZABETH BENSON . I am a widow, and live at Limehonie. I take in clothes to wash—about four weeks ago, I went out at half past eleven—the prisoner was lodging with me—I left him in my kitchen, and nobody else—I returned in twenty minutes, and he was gone—about four o'clock in the afternoon I went to a box, in which I had some money; it was all gone—I had one sovereign, one crown, one shilling and a sixpence there—my box was not locked—I saw the prisoner in a beer-shop about three weeks after, and gave him in charge.

JAMES HOWARD (policeman.) On the evening of the 18th of Oct., I was in Salmon's-lane, Limehouse—the prosecutrix spoke to me—I went to a beer-shop, and took the prisoner—he said he went about ten in the morning and took 1s., and got something to eat; he returned and missed half-a-crown, and he took 6s. 6d. that remained, but he knew nothing about the sove
reign.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

3028.
THOMAS JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Oct., 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
William Henry Brown.

WILLIAM HENRY BROWN . I keep a beer-shop in Bowling-green-lane, Clerkenwell. On the evening of the 24th of Oct., the prisoner came for half a pint of ale—he went into the bar parlour—I saw him take this quart pot, and put it into his pocket—when he went out, I went and stopped him—I told him he had a pot—he said he had no such thing about him—I gave him into custody—the pot was found between my house and where I stopped him.
JOHN VO'LLER (police-constable G 113.) I took the prisoner—I saw the pot about four yards from where he was given into custody.
Prisoner. I never saw it, nor saw a pot but the one I drank out of.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
3029.
WILLIAM WARDELL was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of Sept., 1 chest of drawers, value 2l. 10s.; and 1 mat, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
John Deal, his master: and
EDWARD WARDELL
, for feloniously receiv
ing the same, well knowing them to be stolen; against the Statute, &c., to which

WILLIAM WARDELL pleaded
GUILTY .

WILLIAM WAINE . I am shopman to Mr. John Dent, an upholsterer, in Crawford-street, Marylebone. On the 27th of Sept. a chest of drawers were removed from Montague-street to our warehouse—I missed them in the even
ing—I dismissed William Wardell, who was in the service—on the day after I searched William's premises, and saw a chest of drawers—they were the same that had been taken from my master—the mat produced is also his, and worth 1s. 6d.
JAMES COULTHARD . I am in the prosecutor's service—on the 27th of Sept. I assisted William Wardell to remove a chest of drawers—I have seen them since.

MORRIS ELLICOTT . I am a shoemaker, and live in Highworth-street, Lis
son-grove. William Wardell lodged at my house—on the 27th Sept. he brought home a chest of drawers—I assisted him to put them in the kitchen.

JOHN PHELPS (police-constable D 13.) About five in the afternoon of the 29th of Sept, I went to the house of Edward Wardell, in Upper Boston-place, and saw a mat there—at nine the same evening I took him into custody for reoeiving stolen property—he made no answer—I said I had found a door-mat at his house—he said he had bought it of his brother for 4s. 8d.—I had not then found the chest of drawers—I went to Stafford-street, Lisson-grove, and found a chest of drawers—I have shown them to Waine.

RICHARD STANFORD . I am pot-boy at the Hope and Anchor, in Hereford-street, Lisson-grove. On Friday evening, the 29th, about eight o'clock, Ed
ward Wardell came and asked me to assist him with a chest of drawers a few doors off—I went with him to No. 4, Highworth-street, and assisted him to take a pair of drawers to Stafford-street, and left them in the front parlour—he gave me 4d. and some beer.

EDWARD WARDELL—
NOT GUILTY .

3030.
WILLIAM WARDELL was again indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of August, 3 hammers, value 3s.; 1 chisel, 1s.; 1 hone, 1s.; 1 ladle, 1s. 6d.; 1 pewter pot, 1s.; 4 brushes 4s.; 4 door-plates, 10s.; 1 spoon, 6d.; 1 cigar-case, 1s. 6d.; 3 pillow-cases, 3s.; 1 mat, 1s. 6d.; 1 rug, 3s.; 1 clothes-horse, 2s.; and 1 pair of wooden steps, 2s.; the goods of
John Dent, his master; to which he pleaded

>GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Eighteen Months.

3031.
JOHN GREEN and
WILLIAM WEAVER were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of Oct., 1 basket, value 1s.; and 1 bushel of dam
sons, 5s.; the goods of
Gabriel Hards, the master of Green.

RICHARD MOORE . I am beadle of Covent-garden market. On the after
noon of the 2nd of Oct. I was employed watching Green, who was servant to the prosecutor, who keeps a shop in the market—I saw Green empty some damsons out of a bushel basket, at the prosecutor's stand, into a smaller sieve which laid on the ground—Weaver was close by—Green left the basket for some minutes, between Weaver's brother's stand and the prosecutor's—Weaver was near him at the time, and could see what was done—I made some inquiries of the prosecutor's daughter, then went back to the stall, and the basket was gone.
Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Weaver is a porter employed in the market? A. Yes.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Weaver's brother has a stand next to the prosecutor's? A. Yes—he was between the two stands—there were no damsons on Weaver's stand—I have not told any one that they must not come up to give the prisoners a character, nor said, that if any money was sub
scribed towards the prisoner's defence, those persons should never be em
ployed in the market again—Green lives in Duke's-court, Bow-street.

JOSEPH BAXTER . I am a porter in Covent-garden market, and live in Great Wild-street. On the afternoon of the 2nd of Oct. I watched Green by desire of Moore—he was standing at his master's stand—he turned, out, some damsons, and put them down, partly in his master's stand and partly in Wea
ver's brother's stand—he then spoke to Weaver—they talked together two or three minutes—after that Green went back to his work—Weaver followed him, and took the same damsons on his head to Duke's-court—he took the basket off his head, and put it into the passage, inside the door of No. 14—he came out with the empty basket—I saw Green taken, and heard Johnson ask him if he had authorized Weaver to take any damsons—he said no—he asked if he had authorized any one else—he made no reply—Johnson asked Weaver what became of those damsons he had taken up Bow-street—he said he had taken them to Green's house, by Green's direction—(Green lives at No. 16, and Wearer lives at No. 14)—I then went to No. 16, Duke's court, with Weaver—I heard him ask Green's wife where those damsons were that he took there a little while ago for John—she denied all knowledge of them—I am positive Weaver took them to No. 14—I stood in the court till he came out with the empty basket.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. How long was Weaver in the house before he came out? A. About half an hour—it was a foreign basket—there is an enormous quantity of foreign fruit sold in the market—I was walking up and down, while I was waiting there—Weaver took the basket a little before three o'clock in the afternoon—there were a great many people about—Weaver's brother has a stand outside his shop, and the pro
secutor has the same—Green was at his own work at his master's stand, not inside the shop—Green gave no directions to Weaver, to my knowledge—Weaver was at the end of Russel-street when Green went to speak to him in the first instance.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Do not you know that Weaver keeps a greengrocer's shop? A. Yes—I was not above three doors from him when he went into the house—when Green took the basket, Weaver's stood was shut—there were other baskets about there.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When you were in this court, were you in a situa
tion to see whether Weaver came out of No. 14 to go to No. 16? A. Yes, I can positively say he never came out of No. 14 till he came out with the empty basket, and he then came out of the court—I have no doubt it was the same basket.

FREDERICK JOHN JOHNSON . I am a constable of Covent-garden market. On the 2nd of Oct. I saw Weaver in Bow-street, with a sieve on his head—I could not see whether it was full or empty—he was walking in the direction to Duke's-court—I saw Baxter, and made a communication to him—after he had watched he made a communication to me—I took Green into custody, and asked if he authorized any one to take any damsons from his master's stand—he said "No"—I asked if he were sure of it—he said "Yes"—I asked if he authorized Slaymaker to take any—he said "No"—I asked if he authorized any one else—he said "No"—I took him to the station—I took Weaver the same day, and asked where he took that sieve to, which I saw on his head—he said, "To Green's house"—I asked by whose authority—he said, "By Green's."

GABRIEL HARDS . I am a fruit-salesman, and have a stand in Covent-garden market—I live in Basing-place, Lambeth. Green was in my employ about four years—he never sold, or had authority to sell for me, without my daughter was present—I know Weaver—I had made no sale to him of any damsons on the 2nd of Oct., and he had no authority from me to remove any—when I left the market there were upwards of forty if not fifty baskets of damsons—some damsons were pointed out to me by the officer as takes by a man named Slaymaker—the others were not found.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. I believe Green was a tenant of yours? A. Yes, he occupied a room of mine in this house in Duke's-court—the other rooms are let out to a number of persons—I had no knowledge of where Weaver lived till after the damsons were taken there—he has a greengrocer's shop at No. 14—I searched that house about an hour after.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

WEAVER—
GUILTY . Aged 53.—
Confined Six Months.

GREEN—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—(See the next Case.)

3032. The said
JOHN GREEN and
JOHN SLAYMAKER were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of Oct., 1 basket, value 1s.; and 1 bushel of dam
sons, 5s.; the goods of
Gabriel Hards, the master of Green.

REBECCA WILLIAMS HARDS . I live with my father, Gabriel Hards, a fruit-salesman in Covent-garden market, and live in Basing-place, Lambeth. About four o'clock in the afternoon of the 2nd of Oct. I was attending to my father's stall—Slaymaker was employed in the next stall—there was a sieve of damsons partly on my father's stall, and partly on the next—Slay
maker came and took up the sieve—Green was at our stall at the time, and I was at the stand outside the shop—Slaymaker put the sieve on his head, went towards Bow-street, and told Green if any one wanted him he should he back in ten minutes—I told Green I did not believe that sieve of damsons belonged to Bedell, which is the name Slaymaker goes by in the market—Green said, "O yes, it does, we have no damsons on that side"—I know we had damsons on that side—my father had permission to place his on that side—I have seen Green emptying them from there, by my father's desire—in a quarter of an hour Slaymaker returned—I asked him if he had not made a mistake in taking that sieve of damsons, as I had noticed that German sieve standing there for some time, and thought it was my father's—he said, "No, they were not, and as for German sieves, I can show you half a score down in the cellar"—the damsons are worth 5s. a bushel—Weaver's stall was shut up at the time, and no business going on—the shutters were closed.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Slaymaker was in Weaver's service? A. Yes—there were no goods outside Weaver's stalll—this sieve was just behind some tiers of baskets, on the boundary between our stall and
Weaver's—I know there were none of Weaver's on our side, and there were not any open for sale.

MARIA BOSHER . I am the wife of Thomas Bosher, and keep a green
grocer's shop in Drury-lane. Between four and five o'clock, on the 2nd of Oct., I was in the parlour—I saw a man bringing a basket of damsons into the shop—I do not know who it was—I did not expect any damsons—I got out of my parlour to go and see, but the man was gone, leaving the dam
sons—I do not know Slaymaker—I could not say whether he is the man.

JOSEPH BAXTER . I am a porter in the market. On the 2nd of Oct. I saw Slaymaker take this basket of damsons on his head—he went up Bow-street, and through Long-acre, to Bosher's shop in Drury-lane, and left them there—I have since seen the basket—it is the same.

FREDERICK JOHN JOHNSON . I am a beadle of the market. Between four and five o'clock, on the 2nd of Oct., I saw Slaymaker go across the market, up Bow-street—I went to Bosher's shop, and found a basket of damsons there—I showed them to the prosecutor, and they were given up to him—this is the basket—I asked Slaymaker where he took the sieve of damsons to which I saw him carry up Russell-street—he said he had taken them to Bosher's, in Drury-lane, under the immediate authority of Green—I asked what he was going to receive—he said, "All I shall have will be a drop of gin or a drop of beer for my trouble."
MR. HORRY. Q. Did he use the words "immediate authority?" A. Words to that effect.

JOHN WEAVER . I keep a stall next to the prosecutor. About four o'clock in the afternoon of the 2nd of Oct. my stall was closed for business, and had been for nearly two hours—Slaymaker had no authority to take any damsons from my stall—I had no goods at all between my stall and Mr. Hards'.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Have you not German sieves in your cellar? A. Not one of my own in my cellar or on my stand—when my stall is closed, other parties use it—Slaymaker occasionally works for other parties.
GABRIEL HARD . I have seen the basket and some damsons—I have no doubt they are mine.
(Slaymaker received a good character; and John Fothergill, a slop-seller, gave Green a good character.)

GREEN—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

SLAYMAKER—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

3033.
CHARLES ANDERSON and
CHARLES ROCKLEY were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 5th of Oct., 1 bag, value 1s.; 2 thimbles, 2s.; 1 pencil-case, 3s.; 1 tablet, 4s.; 2 needle-cases, 1s.; 1 pair of scissors, 6d.; and 1 handkerchief, 6d.; the goods of
Mary Ann Pearce, from her person; and that Anderson had been before convicted of felony.

MARY ANN PEARCE . I live on Dane-hill, Margate. At half-past eight o'clock at night, on the 5th of Oct., I was walking with Mrs. Taylor, in the New-road, with a bag on my arm, containing two thimbles and the other things stated—I saw Anderson come by me, and another man run across the road—I felt the strings of my bag cut, and my bag was gone—this is it.

ANN TAYLOR . I am the wife of Richard Taylor. At half-past eight o'clock that evening, I was walking with the prosecutrix—I saw the bag on her arm—Anderson passed close by me—the prosecutrix held up her arm, and said, "Oh, that fellow!"—I saw that the strings of her bag were cut—I went imme
diately across the road after Anderson—he had been near enough to cut the strings—I caught hold of Anderson's arm, and Rockley stopped me—he held
me, and prevented my running after Anderson—he asked me what was the matter—Anderson got away—I have no doubt he is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. This was opposite Judd-street? A. Yes—Anderson had not got above three steps before I went after him—he passed in front of me, and was in front the whole way—he kept in the middle of the road—I saw no omnibus coming, and none interrupted me—I saw no one till Rockley stopped me—I had just got hold of Anderson when I was stopped by Rockley, and Anderson went up Judd-street—I was not detained above a quarter of a minute.
Rockley. Q. When I was at the station, did not you say you could not swear to me? A. No, I swear you are the man who caught my arm, and stopped me from running after Anderson—I have no doubt of you.

WILLIAM PATTERSON (police-constable E 25.) I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw Anderson running—he threw this bag from his hand into an area—it was brought up in my presence—I saw several persons running.

JOHN VESPER (police-constable E 158.) I saw Anderson running, and a cry of "Stop thief" after him—I took him—the prosecutrix, Mrs. Taylor, and several other persons, came up—I took Anderson to the station—after I had him, Rockley came up, and said Anderson was not the man who com
mitted the offence, that I had got the wrong person in custody—he was secured.
Rockley. At the time of the robbery I was at home in Stanmore-street—I was fetched by Anderson's sister—I went, and was taken.
JOHN ROWE (police-constable E 91.) I produce a certificate of Anderson's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.

ANDERSON—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

ROCKLEY*—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

3034.
FRANCIS JACK was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Oct., 1 dead duck, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Goddard.

JOHN ROBERT DARK . I am in the service of Thomas Goddard, poulterer, Maida-hill. On the 14th of Oct, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, the prisoner and another man came to the shop—the other man bought some bacon, and the prisoner took a dead dock—I heard the paper it was on rattle—I looked, and it was gone—I ran after him down North-street, and saw the duck in his hand—I pursued him to Carlile-street, and before I lost sight of him I told him I should see him at Pope's on Monday, and would give him in charge—he dropped the duck—I am sure of that.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not the other man speak some words to him? A. Yes—I saw the prisoner with a duck, talking to a green
grocer—I heard the prisoner ask the green-grocer if he would bring it back, and he said he would not—he offered the duck to me to take back, and I said I would not—he put it under his coat, and then dropped it—he ap
peared perfectly sober—I had a scuffle with him—he got away—I hal
looed after him, and he came back to strike the green-grocer—my master came and held him, and I fetched the policeman—I knew the prisoner when he was at Mr. Charles Brooks's.
EDWARD FOSKETT . I saw the prisoner take the duck, and run away with it.
EDWARD BRIGDEN (police-constable S 125.) I took the prisoner—he was not drunk.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know that? A. By his appearance.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Two Months.

3035.
ROBERT ROBINSON ALEXANDER was indicted
for embes
zlement.

JAMES SCOTT . I keep the Uxbridge Arms, at Notting-hill. I deal with Messrs. Strong and Larchin for beer—on the 20th of Sept., I paid the pri
soner 19l. 19s. 11d. on account of the firm—he gave me this receipt.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you dealt with the firm? A. From the 8th of last March—I knew Mr. Larchin for some years—the prisoner was a collecting clerk—I made his acquaintance through Larebin and Co.

WILLIAM GLASS . I keep the King's Arms beer-shop at Pentonville. I deal with Strong and Larchin—on the 21st of Sept. I paid the prisoner 2l., and on the 23rd of Sept. 3l., on account of the firm—this is the prisoner's signature in my book.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been a customer of the house, introduced by the prisoner? A. Yes—I only knew I was dealing with that house through him—I believe the prisoner kept a beer-shop at Wai worth—the mo
nies I paid him were on account of the goods I had had.

SAMUEL STRONG . I am a brewer, and am in partnership with Henry Lar
chin and Henry Smith, at Ratcliff-cross—the prisoner was in our service—it was his duty to receive money, collect orders, and to account to me for the money he received—he had an allowance of ten per cent, and twopence in the pound for expenses—there is no commission remaining due to him on any monies that he has paid—he has never accounted to me for 19l. 19s. 11d. from Mr. Scott, on the 20th of Sept.—on the following day I learned he had received 20l., and I asked him the reasons he had not paid it, with other money he had paid on the Wednesday—he said he had not enough by 1l., and he would bring it on Saturday—he promised to call with it—I did not see him afterwards—he has never accounted to me for 2l. and 3l., received from Mr. Glass on the 21st and 23rd of Sept.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you make any inquiry whether he had received these two sums? A. I had not an opportunity of doing so—I did not see him afterwards—he solicited us to employ him—we did not go to him—there was no writing executed between us—I told him he ought to keep a book to enter the money, and, in fact, he had a book when he brought the first money—he was to pay me once or twice a week—not less than once a week cer
tainly—there was an understanding about that.

Q. Have you not been in correspondence with his attorney, and found, on application, that 60l. was claimed for balance due from you to him? A. No; no claim of 60l. has been made on us by Salmon and Long, on his account—we received a letter on the 8th or 9th of Oct. from them, in which they say that there was a large sum due, but they do not state the amount—that was before I gave the prisoner into custody—his attorney made a demand on us for money, in answer to a letter we wrote to the prisoner, addressed to his own house—I rather think we gave him into custody the day after we re
ceived the letter—I will not swear when we received the letter—I believe it was not nearly a week after we received it that we gave him in charge, but I cannot tell—he was not to receive a commission upon all the custom he got, but upon all the monies he paid in, because there were a great many bad debts—I believe he went about to the publicans, and drank with them to get custom—I settled with him last on the 20th of Sept.—here is the book—I never had a general account—I always paid him as he went on—I received 5l. 19s. 10d. on the 20th of Sept, as a balance of an ac
count of Scott and Glass—I do not know when I had received any money before that had any reference to Scott—I have received from the prisoner, in

the course of twelve months, 600l. or 700l.—it was not 1000l.—the first time he paid me money, I told him he ought to keep a book, and, in fact he did then—I certainly saw the book two or three times—it is four or five months since I saw it—I cannot recollect when it was—I was in the habit of entering in my book all the money I received from him—I will swear I always entered it in the course of the day—I may have taken the money, and put it in my iron chest, and entered it the same day, perhaps half a dozen times, but have not entered it at the moment—I have not done so twenty times—I have received lumping sums from him on account—in Sept. I received 25l. of him through Cook, and that he balanced with me on the 20th of Sept.—here it is in the book—I had received the 25l. of him before that, and we balanced it on that day—I do not know what period of the supply of goods this 25l. ran over—I asked him about this 19l. 19s. 11d. on Thursday the 21st—I think I have not stated that it was several days after—I believe I said it was the next day—the 20l. of Mr. Scott's ran over a period of a fortnight—we never settled with Mr. Scott at all—it was a running account—it was on the 21st that I received an account that he had received money—I do not know whether he remained at home from then till the 10th of Oct.—we sent for him two or three times—we sent Mr. Cook, and I believe he saw him—I never was at his house but once, that might be on the 26th—I believe in answer to that call we had a letter—we let the prisoner be at large two or three days after that—we consulted our attorney—here is a small paper on which I settled an account—here is 36l. 16l., 1l. 16s. poundage to the cus
tomer, and 4l. 0s. 2d. for his expenses—it is not marked expenses—it is my writing—the last I received was this 25l., about the 18th of Sept.—I did not swear it was the 20th—the balance was settled on the 20th—it was on the 18th be paid that 25l.—Mr. Cook has the memorandum that he received 25l.—Mr. Collins, Mr. Cook, and Mr. Larchin, used to receive money on account, as well as I did—I was not present when the prisoner was taken—he did not claim a commission on such beer as we sold to customers whom he had intro
duced—he did not say, that after he got an order or two, instead of sending him I went myself—we have furnished beer to Mr. Lane, since he introduced him to us, to the amount of 30l., and have received 34l. from Mr. Curtis—I do not believe the prisoner had anything to do with Mr. Beal—I think we have received 40l. from Mr. Scott—we have not received 43l. from Mr. Jones—there is an account—I am sorry to say that we have not received 30l. from Mr. Miller, there is not 30l. due—he received 10l.—I believe there in 30l. due from Mr. Glass.

COURT. Q. Did the prisoner make a claim against you before you took him into custody? A. Yes, but he never made any claim himself—we first made our claim on him on the 3rd of Oct.—we sent to him repeatedly.

MR. HORRY. Q. You sent to him? A. Yes—he sent a person to say he would come, but he did not—this memorandum was made before him—the sums which have been mentioned just now have been received since he was in custody—excepting these sums, there is no other claim for commission against us—he was not entitled to receive any commission till the money was paid—we always allowed it to him at the time he paid the money—if he had handed money to any one of the clerks, or to Mr. Larchin, it was his duty to account to me.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 41.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Year.

3036.
WILLIAM NUTTALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of Oct., 56lbs. weight of lead, value 7s., the goods of
John Till; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EDWARD CHAPMAN . I am a coach-maker, and live in Harrow-street. I was employed at some premises in Park-street, Camden-town—the prisoner was on the premises when I went there—I took off three pieces of lead—one piece I threw down into the yard, the other two laid on the party wall—that was about eleven or twelve o'clock, on the 3rd of Oct.—about five I received a communication from the policeman—I then missed the lead.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Which did you miss? A. The piece that was thrown into the yard—this is it—I know it by the way it was rolled up.

JAMES HARROD (police-constable S 179.) On the 3rd of Oct. I was on duty in Park-street, opposite the gateway of Mr. Till—I saw the prisoner come from the premises with this lead on his shoulder—I communicated with Harding.

JOHN HARDING (police-constable S 166.) I had information from Harrod—I went to a marine-store dealers, and saw the prisoner in the shop—I kept where they could not see me—I saw the marine-store dealer put some money on the counter, and this lead was in the scale—after the prisoner left I asked where he got the lead—he said where he was putting down other—I asked who authorised him—he said the foreman—he went back to the pre
mises, and said the foreman was not there, but there was a man on the roof would make it all right—he asked if I was on duty, and said, "You need not see it—it is all right;"—in going to the station, he said he had made a fool of himself a good many times, but he thought he had done so once too often now.

Cross-examined. Q. Where was it he went to? A. To Mr. Tili's yard in Park-street, Camden-town—the man came off the roof—I asked if he had authorised this man to sell any lead—he said no, he had desired him in the morning to take nothing from the premises.
WILLIAM HOGBEN . I am foreman to Mr. John Till—these premises in Park-street are his—I did not authorise the prisoner to take the lead.
JOSEPH WALKER (police-sergeant D 5.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined One Year.

3037.
RICHARD GARRATT was indicted
for knowingly and feloniously receiving, on the 4th of Oct., 3 skins of leather, value 2l. 16s.; the goods of
Joseph Otter.
JOSEPH OTTER . I am a harness-maker, and live in Eyre-street, Piccadilly—I have no doubt these skins of leather are mine—I saw them safe on the 3rd of October.
WILLIAM PREESON . These skins were brought to me for sale by Samuel Hodges.
SAMUEL HODGES . These skins were brought to me by the prisoner, on the Friday after the 3rd of Oct.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. It was on the Wednesday, was it not? A. No—on Wednesday he brought a piece to me to ask if I would buy it.
NOT GUILTY .

3038.
JOHN JOHNSON and
JAMES HALEY were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 13th of Oct., 49lbs. weight of nails, value 2l.; the goods of
Wil
liam Reid and others: and that Haley had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN FIELD . I am a veterinary surgeon, employed on the premises of William Reid and others, in Liquorpond-street—they had some nails of a particular sort—I lost some of them, to the value of about 40s.—I beleive these produced are them—they correspond in every respect.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What nails are they? A. For horses shoes—I gave the description for the pattern of them—I have never seen any like them—I cannot say when I had last seen any of these—we have missed nails for the last two years; but I cannot say that all these left at one time.
LEWIS DURANT . I am foreman to Mr. Branscomb, an ironmonger—we supply the prosecutors with these nails—they are made for no one but them.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you not reason to believe that there are other nails of this sort made? A. I do not think there are—they are drawn from under the head very differently to what the generality of nails are.

HENRY REDMAN (police-constable G 140.) I stopped the prisoners with these nails in Goswell-street, on the evening of the 13th of October—Haley had them on his head—I asked Johnson if they belonged to him—he said they did, and that he bdught horse-parings—Haley said he worked for Johnson.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he bought horse-parings all over London? A. Yes, and that he picked the nails out of the horse-parings—I believe these nails have not been on a horse's foot.

JOHN FIELD
re-examined. I believe people in shoeing horses, drop some nails on the ground—a poor man going about buying the horse-parings might get a few nails, but very few, and they would not be in this condition—a few of these are rusty, but not many.

Haley's Defence. I am in the employ of Johnson; we travel all over London; I have the sifting of the parings, and I put the new nails on one side, the old ones on the other, and take them to a farrier's shop and sell them.
JOSEPH GINGER (police-constable G 137.) I produce a certificate of Haley's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Six Months.

HALEY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

3039.
JAMES SMITH and
THOMAS OWEN were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of Oct., 1 coat, value 4s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 9s. 6d.; and 1 handkerchief, 6d.; the goods of
John O'Reilly; to which

OWEN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Four Months.

JOHN O'REILLY . I live in Orchard-street, Lisson-grove. Owen lived in the same room—I left on the morning of the 16th of Oct.—my things were all there—I returned about a quarter to twelve o'clock, and missed the articles stated—these are them—Smith did not lodge there.

SAMUEL GREEN . I slept in the same room. I was going home at eight o'clock in the morning, on the 16th of Oct., and met the two prisoners going to the pawnbroker's—Smith had a bundle—he had lodged at the house, but not then.
JOSEPH DONALDSON . I am in the employ of Mr. Haywood, a pawnbroker. I took in these articles of Smith, on the 16th.
Smith's Defence. When I met Owen I had not the least knowledge that he stole these things; I pawned them by his desire.

SMITH—
NOT GUILTY .

3040.
JANE MALLARD was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 23rd of Oct., 3dwts. of gold, value 10s. 6d., the goods of
Henry Williamson, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

HENRY WILLIAMSON . I live in Perceval-street, Clerkenwell. I had a boy in my employ—I charged him with stealing some gold from me—in con
sequence of what he said, I went to the prisoner's house, in Fox-place, Clerkenwell, where the boy lived—I showed the prisoner the gold I lost, and the said she had picked up a piece like that in Clerkenwell-close, and sold it to Mr. Hearn for 10s.

RICHARD LIDGETT . I lived with Mr. Williamson. He charged me with stealing gold—I took three bits, at three different times, home to the prisoner, and she told me she sold them—the first morning I took it she gave me 6d.—I took a bit on the Saturday morning, and she gave me 1s.—I told her I had got it away from my place.
CHARLES SAUNDERS . I am shopman to Mr. Hearn. I bought a piece of gold, but I cannot say of whom—I buy pieces of gold of poor women like the prisoner without knowing who they are.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going up Clerkenwell-close, and picked up a piece of blue paper, and in it was a thin piece of gold; I did not know what it was; I took it to this young man, and asked him; he said it was gold; when Lidgett came home I told him, and he said, "You ought to give me part of it."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 53.—
Confined Six Months.

3041.
JANE BOWAN was indicted
for stealing on the 21st of October, I brooch, value 5s.; and 1 necklace, 5s.; the goods of
Richard Huntley, her master.

ELIZABETH HUNTLEY . I am the wife of Richard Huntley—we live in William-street, Pentonville. The prisoner came into my service on the 20th of Oct.—I had a brooch and a necklace—I have seen some studds, which belong to our lodger.
NOT GUILTY .

3042.
JANE BOWAN was again indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 1 pair of shirt studds, value 2s., the goods of
Edward Croucher.
The prosecutor's name being Crouch, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

3043.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Oct., 1 truck, value 8l.; 7 1/2 lbs. weight of tea, 1l. 17s.; 71bs. weight of coffee, 12s. 10d.; 69lbs. weight of tea, 2l.; 10lbs. weight of candles, 4s. 6d.; 1lb. weight of rice, 5d.; and 3/4 lb. weight of cocoa, 7d.; the goods of
Richard Sexton and another; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

RICHARD SEXTON . I am a grocer, and live in High-street, Newington. I had a truck on the 12th of Oct. at my house—it contained 7 1/2 lbs. of tea, and the other things stated—I sent the whole of them in the truck, by Edward Copas, to take to my different customers—I saw the truck the next day at the station, with the different articles.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you put the articles up? A. I put up some, and my man put up the others—I superintended it—I have one partner.
EDWARD COPAS . I went to Mr. Huntley's, in Pump-row, Old-street, and began to deliver some of these things, and, while I was inside, a man took the truck, and the property—this is it.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you delivered any of the order? A. Yes, three parcels—I left the truck for about ten minutes, and nobody with it—it was about five o'clock.

JAMES WHITCOMBE . I live with my father, in Norris-street, Hoxton, I saw Copas go into the house—I then saw the prisoner take the truck away, with these things in it—there was a bag in it—he took it out, carried it through the street, rested at a public-house, and then took it away with him.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I work for a cabinet carver—I was sitting on some logs in Pump-row—was out for my tea half-hour—I had never seen the prisoner before—I am quite sure he is the person—I saw him for about half an hour—after I had told Copas, I looked for a policeman—I found two, and told them—they went after the prisoner, and caught him with the bag—I had not lost sight of him—he was on the other side of the way.

JOHN JONES (policeman.) Whitcombe told me that a man had stolen the bag off the truck, and said, "Yonder he goes"—he pointed the prisoner out to me and the other policeman—we took him with it—the prisoner appeared quite sober.
DANIEL BLAY (City police-constable No. 159.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3044.
CLARA LEWIS and
JAMES GLENDON were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 18th of Oct., 1 watch, value 6l.; 1 watch chain, 15s.; and 1 watch
key, 5s.; the goods of
Samuel Irvine.

SAMUEL IRVINE . I am butler to Samuel Duckworth, Esq. A few minutes before one o'clock, on the 18th of October, my watch, with a gold chain and seal, was on a nail over the fire-place in the pantry, which is about fire yards from the area door—I returned in half an hour, and they were gone—this is the watch-chain and seal.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What time had you seen it safe? A. A few minutes before one—the bell rang, and the kitchen-maid went up to answer it—the watch must have been taken about that period—I do not believe that while the kitchen-maid went up, the party came and com
mitted the robbery—there was another person taken up, but not in conse
quence of what the kitchen-maid said—she could not identify that person.
WILLIAM EDWARD VINRON . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. This watch was pawned on the 18th of Oct., before four o'clock, by the prisoner Lewis.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know her? A. Yes; she frequently pledges—I do not know that she keeps a bad house—I offered her 2l. for the watch—she then said I knew whose it was, but did not mention the name of any person—I do not recollect her saying that a gentleman in her house asked her to pawn it.
JOSEPH KENT (policeman.) I took Lewis—I told her it was for pledging this watch—she said, when at the station-house, that she had pledged it.
HENRY WYATT . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. This seal, chain, and key, were pawned by Glendon on the 18th of Oct., about three o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know there was another person with him? A. Yes; because when I asked him for a halfpenny for the ticket, he said he would go and get it—he stepped out and got a pennypiece, some person must have given it him.

JULIA PHILLIPS . I am the wife of Mr. Charles Phillips, a bootmaker, in Fleet-street, Blackfriars—I know the prisoner Lewis—I do not know what sort of a house she keeps—I live a few doors off her—she was taken up on

a Thursday—I went to her house at eleven o'clock on the day before—I was mending a counterpane, and I took it there to sit with Lewis—I am positive I got there as near eleven o'clock as could be—Glendon was there when I went—he went out, and returned about half-past twelve—from that time I did not lose sight of them at all, till I left at two o'clock.
COURT. Q. How came you to remember the day? A. It was the day before they were taken.

LOUISA JOHNSON . I lodge at Lewis's—Glendon lives there—I remember seeing Lewis the day before she was taken up—I got up at eight o'clock in the morning, and was in Lewis's company all day long—the was not out from twelve o'clock till two—I saw Glendon there—he went out at a quarter to twelve, and returned at half-past—I saw him there during the remainder of the day.

COURT. Q. You know them both very well, do you? A. Yes; I re
member the day, because it was the day before they were taken.

CHARLES SMITH . I know Lewis's house—I remember Wednesday the 18th of Oct.—the prisoners were taken on the Thursday—on that Wednesday I was at their house from about ten minutes to one till half-past, or from twenty minutes to half-past—I saw them both there.
NOT GUILTY .

3045.
JOHN HARDEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Oct., 1 sextant, value 5l.; the goods of
Samuel Snell, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

BARTHOLOMEW WILLIAM RIDDELL . I am steward of the barque the Dale Park, which was in the West India Dock—I saw-the sky-light safe about twenty minutes past five, on the 20th of Oct.—the watchman came to me about ten minutes to six—the sky-light was then off, and the sextant was gone—it belonged to the captain, Samuel Snell—it has not been found since—the sideboard drawer was open, and other things were gone.

THOMAS GLADWELL . I am an officer. At a quarter-past six that day the prisoner came to the dock-gate, and presented me with a pass for a sex
tant—I heard something rattle in it, and I said, "What is this?"—he said, "Some of the glasses are broken, I am going to get it repaired; I am learning navigation"—I believed, from the pass, that be belonged to a vessel—he was coming out of Limehouse basin entrance—there were a great many people came out, but none with a sextant.

Prisoner's Defence. The person who opens the door at the Haymarket, can prove I was at the theatre door that evening before the gates were open; I went in, and after the first act I came out, and went to a public-house; the man said, "Can I have half a pint of beer with you;" I said, "Yes."
GUILTY .

3046.
JOHN HARDEN was again indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of Oct., 1 jacket, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, 3s.; 4 half-crowns, and 2 shillings, the property of
John Gathard, in a vessel, in a port of entry and discharge.

JOHN GATHARD . I am apprentice, on board the ship Arab, of Bristol. On the 5th of Oct. the prisoner came on board, and said he was an appren
tice out of his time—I am sure he is the man—I left him in charge of the vessel while I went to my dinner—I came back and found my box broken open, and missed these things—they have not been found since—I cannot say whether there was any one else on board.
NOT GUILTY .

3047.
JOHN HARDEN was again indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 1 cruet-stand, value 2s.; 6 cruets, 6s.; and 1 spoon, 1s.; the goods of
James Gilbert O'Leason, in a vessel, in a port of entry and discharge.

THOMAS DOWNER . I am a constable of the docks. At half-past six o'clock, on the 23rd of Oct., the prisoner was coming out with this cruet
stand, and this paper purporting to be a pass—I took him.

HENRY PAINTER . I am steward of the Hopewell. This cruet-stand be
longs to Captain James Gilbert O'Leason—it was safe after five o'clock, on the 23rd of Oct.—the prisoner had no business with it.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been four years and eleven months serving in a man of war; I got paid off; I went about, and lost all my money; a man came and said, "I can put you in a way to get a few shillings, take this out, and this pass, and I will give you 5s.;" I was taking it out, and was taken.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

3048.
HENRY FREEMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of Oct., 5 yards of doe-skin, value 2l.; the goods of
Peter Shea.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) On the 11th of Oct. I saw the prisoner and a companion go to the prosecutor's shop—his companion took this doe-skin off the counter, and gave it to the prisoner who put it into his lap, and I took him with it.
WILLIAM BROCKLESS . This is the property of Mr. Peter Shea—the officer brought the prisoner and his companion to the door with it—I did not authorize them to take it.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3049.
HENRY CURRALL and
GEORGE PRICE were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of Oct., 1 bottle, value 2d.; and 1 pint of pickled onions, 1s.; the goods of
Hannah Swan.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty on the 14th of Oct.—I saw the prisoners with four other persons walking three by three—I knew them, and watched them—I saw Price go into the prosecutor's shop—Currall put his arm into the shop, and he came away with this bottle in his arms—Price said to one of the others, "I have got it"—I secured Currall in the act of giving the bottle to Price.
JOHN RICHARD RICHARDS . This bottle of pickles is the property of my sister Hannah Swan—I live with her.

CURRALL—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.

PRICE—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

p.hi: Seventh Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
3050.
ANN TAYLOR and
EDWARD RUSH were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of Oct., 30 pairs of shoes, value 3l. 10s.; 1 pair of boots, 3s. 6d.; 2 pairs of clogs, 3s.; 3 pairs of stays, 6s.; 4 pairs of gloves, 3s. 6d.; 1 pair of pattens, 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, 1s.; 2 handkerchiefs, 2s.; 2 caps, 4s.; 1 yard of flannel, 1s. 6d.; 1 collar, 1s. 6d.; 1 yard of linen cloth, 1s. 6d.; and 10 yards of ribbon, 20s.;—Also,
on the 28th of Sept., 4 pairs of boots, value 14s.; 6 pais of shoes, 15s.; and 2 pairs of stays, 15s.;—Also,
on the 1st of Sept., 25 pairs of shoes, 3s.; 3 pairs of boots, 10s.; the goods of
Charles Longland, their master; to all which

TAYLOR pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

RUSH pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Two Months.
(Rush received a good character.)

3051.
JAMES FLETCHER,
GEORGE MEADOWS , and
RICHARD MEADOWS were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of Oct., 31lbs. weight of hair, value 1l.; the goods of
Benjamin Carr, the master of Fletcher, and George Meadows.

BENJAMIN CARR . I am a horse-hair manufacturer, and live in Banner-street, St. Luke's. Fletcher and George Meadows worked in my factory—I rent a place in Golden-lane, where the hair was taken from—on the 16th of Oct. I received a letter—in consequence of that I conferred with the police—the next day I saw a bag containing some hair—it had been taken from Golden-lane—Richard Meadows had a right on the premises at Golden-lane—Fletcher had no business there whatever—I had ordered my foreman on Tuesday morning to let George take this hair to Golden-lane, to have it carded by a steam-press I have there, and to bring it back—he had no right to dispose of it.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How long has Fletcher been with you? A. About eleven years—he bore an excellent character—four or fire months back he asked me to let him have a bale of hair for his son to work at home—I let him have it—he has bought hair of me five or six times—I have two places of business—I rent a steam-press in Golden-lane—the fore
man was stationed in Banner-street.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Richard was in your employ? A. He had been for three or four years, but was not at this time—I should have had no objection to his calling on his brother there.

JAMES BRANNAN (police sergeant G 20.) In consequence of directions from the prosecutor, I went on Tuesday, the 14th of Oct., to a court leading into Golden-lane, where I could watch the entrance leading into the factory—I saw Fletcher standing at the corner of Arthur-street-leading to the prosecutor's factory—I pointed him out to Cole—he had no appearance of bulk about him—he went towards the factory—in three-quarters of an hour he came from the entrance of the court—there was no thoroughfare, so that he must have come from the factory—he had a bag nearly full—he passed me with it in Play-house-yard—I watched outside a public-house—he went in, and Redman followed George and Fletcher into the house—I had seen George three or four times before Fletcher went into the house—(I had first seen George com
ing from the prosecutor's residence in Banner-street, about 300 yards off—he went to the factory)—they staid in the public-house three or four minutes—Redman came out before them—George came towards me, and went towards the City, and I followed Fletcher with Redman—he turned round in Chis well-street, saw me, and went into a public-house—I followed, told him I belonged to the police, and wanted to know where he got this hair—he said, "I bought it in the Curtain-road"—I said, "How came you this way from the Curtain-road?"—he said, "Oh, this I bought in Smithfield"—I said, "Which way did you come?"—he said, "Through Long-lane and Barbican"—I asked if he had called anywhere—he at first said no—I asked if he did not call on some one in Golden-lane—he said, "Yes, I did"—I found this hair in the bag.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Was Richard admitted to bail on the first occasion? A. Yes.

HENRY REDMAN (police-constable C 24.) I was with Brannan and Cole—I saw George Meadows come from the entrance of the factory into Golden-lane—he looked right and left, as if looking who were about—Fletcher then came from the entrance of the factory, and met George—they went into a public-house at the left hand side of Golden-lane—Fletcher had a bag—it was such a sized bag as George must have seen it—George did not have the bag—I followed them into the public-house—Fletcher put the bag down—they

had a pint of porter and half-a-quartern of gin—Fletcher then took the bag across his shoulder—George wished him good day, and said, "I shall see you again to-morrow"—I took George—he said he knew nothing about the bag or the stealing of it.

ROBERT COLE (policeman.) I was with Brannan and Redman—I saw Fletcher going to the factory without anything—after that I saw George come from the factory, followed by Fletcher, who was carrying a bag—I went back to the factory, and found Richard there, and a key on him—I fitted that key to the padlock of the warehouse the hair was in, and it opened it with ease.

BENJAMIN CARR
re-examined. I believe this hair to be mine—it is im
possible to swear to it—it is just the kind that was ordered to be given out that day—George ought to have brought back some hair to my house in Banner-street—he would not be doing right in taking it anywhere else—he had no right to be bringing this hair back—it is just as it was sent there—this is my bag, but on one occasion my foreman lent Fletcher a bag to carry hair in, and'it might be this bag.

FLETCHER—
GUILTY . Aged 48.

GEORGE MEADOWS—
GUILTY . Aged 27.

RICHARD MEADOWS—
NOT GUILTY .

3052.
THOMAS ASHMORE was indicted
for feloniously receving, on the 10th of Jan., 9 shirts, value 2l. 19s. 6d.; and 1 scarf, 5s. 6d.; the goods of
John Mills; well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JOHN MILLS . I am a hosier, and live in Oxford-street. About two years ago I bought eleven shirts of one Weston—I saw them in my possession last about twelve months ago—I cannot say when I had the scarfs safe, because I have so many of the same description—I never sold the shirts.
Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Had you a man in your employ of the name of Gravel? A. Yes, till last April—he robbed me to a very great extent—myself, a boy, and a young man serve in my shop.

WILLIAM WESTON . I am a manufacturer of shirts. About two years and a half ago I had shirts in my possession—I know this one—I sold it to be prosecutor—there were eleven of this kind—this one has my own mark on it.

Cross-examined. Q. What is there particular about it? A. It is marked outside—it has a calico body, with linen collar, front, and wrists—I may sell 200 dozen of these shirts in the course of a year—I know I sold this to Mr. Mills, because I have referred to my book—my brother, who is dead, made the entry—I took them in from Boswell, who was then the work-woman—I know that, because I put the mark on it, and wrote "Boswell" on it—she has not worked for roe since, because she spoiled these goods—she had made hundreds before—all the shirts that come from her do not bear her mark, unless they are badly made—this is the only shirt I speak to.

JOHN ANDERTON . I am out of business. About the 10th of Jan. the pri
soner brought me nine shirts, and asked if I would purchase them—I asked the price—he said, 3s. 6d. a-piece—I gave it him—this is the bill and re
ceipt he gave me in his own handwriting, it is 1l. 11s. 6d.—about two months after I saw him again, in the King of Prussia public-house, in Somerset-place, Hoxton-town—he asked what I meant to do—I said, "I don't know, you know what you have done, you must do the best you can"—he said he was going to surrender, and asked if I was going to say what I gave for them—I

said yes, I was—these shirts have been so long out of ray possession, I cannot say whether they are what I bought of him—to the best of my belief they are—I kept them by me for some time, and gave three of them to Gladwell to pledge.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you by trade? A. A pawnbroker, but I have been out of that business some years—I was in the greengrocery trade—I am now living on my property—I did not fail as a pawnbroker—I did not like the business, and when I was out of my time I did not do any more—I pawned these shirts for 6s.—this bill is in the same state as when I got it from the prisoner—it has never been out of my possession, nor been touched by me or any one else—this writing, and one figure above another, was on it when I received it—the prisoner first put down 2s. 6d.—I said, "You have made a mistake," and he altered it to 3s. 6d.—as far as I can recollect, it was on the 9th of Jan. I bought them.
SARAH JANE GLADWELL . I live in Canal-road, Hoxton. Anderton gave me three shirts, and I pawned them at Mr. Leech's, Hoxton, for 6s.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you a widow? A. Yes—I took the things to pay myself, because Anderton owed me money for washing—I gave the ticket to Anderton.
HENRY LIEBRECHT . I live in Bethnal-green. I was in the service of Mr. Sowerby, late Leech, of Hoxton—I took in these three shirts of Gladwell.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you particularly notice them? A. No more than to see that they were of the value asked.

GEORGE KEMP (policeman.) On the 27th of April I went to Some
set-place, Hoxton, and watched a bouse to see a party who has since been convicted—I saw that party and the prisoner come out of the house together—they turned round and saw me—I saw tht prisoner, and knew him—I went and changed my dress—I was in private clothes—I then followed them to Clerkenwell—I had at that time these five shirts in my possession—I showed them to Mr. Weston and Mr. Mills.

WILLIAM EDWARD BALL (policeman.) On the 27th of April I saw the prisoner—I saw him again on the 13th of Oct., in Shoreditch, and appre
hended him.

JOHN MILLS
re-examined. To the best of my belief, these are the shirts I bought of Weston.
NOT GUILTY .

3053.
TIMOTHY COLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Oct., 5 brass ornaments for gas-lights, value 7s.; and 5 pieces of brass, 7s.; the goods of
William Leman, and another; and fixed to a building.

It being the property of
George Hare and
Oliver Leman, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

3054.
TIMOTHY COLE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Oct., 3 spoons, value 8s.; and 1 pair of sugar-tongs, 4s.; the goods of
William Gear.

WILLIAM GEAR . I keep a coffee-shop, in Bury-street, Bloomsbury. The prisoner was in the habit of coming to my shop—these are my spoons and tongs—I saw the prisoner at my shop about the 9th or 10th of Oct.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you know them by? A. By the marks "E. B. 1780," on two of them—the other is not sufficiently engraved-the tongs have "1793" on them.

HENRY LANGHAM . I am in the employ of David Jones, a pawnbroker, in High Holborn. On the 10th of Oct. the prisoner offered these sugar
tongs to me—I asked who they belonged to—he said to hit father, who lived

Museum-street—I went and found no one lived there of that name—I after
wards saw him near my shop, and gave him into custody.
Cross-examine. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. No—he was in our shop five minutes—I went out, and he went out too, and when I came back he was standing a few houses off.

WILLIAM SINNOCK (policeman.) I went to Mr. Jones's shop at three o'clock in the afternoon, and found the prisoner—he was given into custody—I found the spoons on him—he said they were his father's, and he did not wish him to know it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

3056.
WILLIAM ROWLAND was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Oct., 33lbs. weight of paper, value 4s., the goods of
John Conrad Kohler.

JOHN CONRAD KOHLER . I am an oilman, and live in Marylebone-street. The prisoner was employed in painting my house—I had some waste paper in a loft at the top of the house, in packages similar to these—the prisoner had access to it—He was there two or three days—Here is 13lbs. of paper.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. Have you got much paper in this loft? A. Yes, four or five hundred weight—I cannot say positively whe
ther I have missed any, nor that this is the paper—my family were in the house—I believe there was another man in the house besides the prisoner—I have known him some time—his family are respectable.
COURT. Q. What time used he to come to work? A. About a quarter past six, and went away about six in the evening.

JOHN GRAY (police-constable C 14.) On the 7th of Oct. I was in Rupert-street, Haymarket, and saw the prisoner with two baskets containing this paper—he went into a marine-store shop in Rupert-street, remained there about two minutes, and came out—I followed him to Wardour-street, and asked what he had got in his basket—he said, "Books, which I got from a young man at Hampstead"—I took him, and he said, "You knew me, and suspected me; I got the paper from the top of Mr. Kohler's house in Marylebone, where I was at work."
Cross-examined. Q. Did you tell him to confess? A. No—he did not offer to run away—he said he would go with me.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

3057.
JOHN MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of October, 9 yards of printed cotton, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Morgan.

WILLIAM HAYWARD . I am a porter, and live in Lyall-row, Red Lion Market. About half-past nine o'clock at night, on the 14th of Oct., I saw the prisoner and a girl about seventeen or eighteen years old, standing out
side Mr. Morgan's window—the girl spoke to the prisoner, and he went into the shop—she remained outside—she tapped at the window, and gave some sign to the prisoner, and then she went in—I went to the window, and saw Mr. Morgan showing the girl a blue shawl—I saw the prisoner come out—he had got hold of the side of his coat—he laughed coming out, ran into the road, and ran as fast as he could—I ran after him—when I got near him he turned the first turning from Old-street, and saw there was some one pur
suing—he threw this cotton between my legs—I took it up, and called, "Stop thief"—I took him and brought him back to the shop—I gave the piece of print to Mrs. Morgan.
MARY MORGAN . I am the wife of Thomas Morgan, a linen-draper, in Old-street. This is my husband's print—the prisoner came in and asked the price

of a shawl—he called a girl in afterwards—I showed her the shawl, and told her the price—I went to get some other shawls down—the prisoner went out, and the girl followed him shortly after—I did not see the prisoner again till he was brought back by Hay ward about five minutes after—this print was in the shop that day—it is my husband's.
JOSEPH BRYANT (policeman.) The prisoner was given into my custody—at the station he said some girl wished him to take it.

GUILTY. Aged 12.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

3058.
WILLIAM BURKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 24 cigars, value 6s., the goods of
Salmon Salmon.

RICHARD WITHERS . At a quarter to twelve o'clock on the morning of the 23rd of Oct., I was in Great Turnstile—I saw the prisoner and two others standing at Mr. Salmon's shop—one of them said, "Go in, it is all right"—the young man was cleaning the window—the prisoner went in and helped himself to some cigars on the counter—he put them into his breeches' pocket and came out—the others followed him—they met together in Holborn, and divided the cigars between them—I saw a policeman, and told him—he took the prisoner—the others escaped.

EVE SALMON . I am the wife of Salmon Salmon, a tobacconist, in Great Turnstile. About eleven o'clock, in the morning of the 23rd, I went into the back parlour while the men were cleaning the windows—no one was in the shop—soon after the prisoner was brought back—I looked into a box on the counter, which had had two dozen cigars in it, and found only three left—these are the same sort of cigars.
JAMES WRIGHT (police-constable F 54) I received information, and took the prisoner—I found these two cigars on him.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Two Months.

p.hi: Seventh Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
3059.
GEORGE CHAPPELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Oct., 30 yards of cloth, called Alpaca, value 3l., the goods of
Christopher Leaf.

THOMAS HILL . I am porter to Christopher Leaf, of Wood-street. Be
tween two and three o'clock in the afternoon of the 17th of Oct., the prisoner came, and inquired if our salesman was in the warehouse—I said no, he was at dinner—he said he would call again; and, in going out, I saw him take this piece of goods—I went and overtook him in Mumford-court, about 300 yards from my master's, with this cloth, which is ours.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANS. Q. Do not you know that he had dealings with the salesman? A. Yes.

GUILTY. Aged 52.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Four Months.

3060.
JOHN KENNEDY and
TIMOTHY BRYAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of Sept., at St. Martin-in-the-fields, 47 3/4 yards of kersey
mere, value 16s., the goods of
John Pannett Bull, in his dwelling-house; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EDWIN MUNDAY . I am in the service of Mr. John Pannett Bull, woollen warehouseman, in St. Martin's-lane. On Monday, the 4th of Sept., in con
sequence of information from Collier, I counted the rolls of drab-coloured

cloth, and missed one piece, numbered "8527," from about forty feet from the entrance—it contained 47 3/4 yards, and was worth about 16l.—it had come from the cloth-workers on the 29th of Aug.—on the 14th of Sept. it was produced by the policeman, and I knew it by the ticket, which was still on it.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You never saw it after the 4th? A. I do not know that I ever saw it at all on my master's premises—I only know it was there from the books—this is the book—it is not in my handwriting,

GEORGE WOOD . I am in the prosecutor's service. He does not live in the house—all the young men do—it is in the parish of St. Martin-in-the-Fields—this ticket is my handwriting—it was on the piece of goods when I wrote it.

Cross-examined. Q. You do not know the goods, do you? A. I do not know the colour, nor to what piece of cloth the ticket was attached—I wrote it about the 30th of Aug.—I marked a great many pieces that day, and this was one of them—there is no date upon it.

SARAH COLLIER . I am the wife of Joseph Collier, a tailor, in Porter-street, Newport-market. Between one and two o'clock, on the 4th of Sept., I was passing along Rose-street, Long-acre, and saw Bryan and another man, (not Kennedy,) in a sailor's dress, rather bow-knee'd—the sailor had a roll of cloth—Bryan was in front of the other—I heard the sailor say to Bryan, D—n his eyes if he would carry it any further, he should be nibbled—Bryan said, "D—n your fool's eyes, come along, it is but a step or two further"—they went through the narrow courts, and Bryan tucked the corner of the cloth in that was hanging down—they rolled the cloth into No. 10, Laaenby-court, and then both ran down Conduit-court.

Cross-examined. Q. Where do you live? A. I did live at No. 2, La
zenby-court, close by—I stood at my door, saw where they put the cloth, and watched them—I told my husband directly, and then I went down to Mr. Bull, to see if he had lost it—Bryan was dressed very differently to what he is now—I have seen him dressed nearly the same as he was that day—he had on a pair of dark trowsers, a waistcoat with red on a black ground, and a blouse—I have seen him in a blouse before—I had never spoken to him before.

JOSEPH COLLIER . I am the husband of Sarah Collier. On the 4th of Sept., in consequence of what she said, I went into Rose-street to look for a police
man—on my return I saw four persons in Lazenby-court—Kennedy was one—they had a bundle in a bag, and went along Hart-street—I followed them to Bull-inn-court, then one of them carried the bundle into a public-house, and the others went towards the Strand—I fetched an officer, went into the public-house, and found the bag behind the door—I took it to the station, and found this roll of cloth in it.
Cross-examined. Q. You will not say that Bryan was one of the four men? A. No, he was not one.

ELIZABETH TAYLOR . I am the wife of James Taylor, and live in Boll Inn-court. On the 4th of Sept., between one and two o'clock, I was at my door—I saw two young men pass down the court—Kennedy was one of them—they came into the narrow part of the court, and ran down into the Strand—the other man was dressed in a frock-coat and a broad hat.
GEORGE WESTON (police-constable F 6.) I received a roll of cloth from Hunt, and delivered it to Mr. Bull—I cut this piece off that has the ticketon it—I took Kennedy—he denied the charge.
GEORGE HUNT (police-constable T 26.) I took the cloth from the public-house, and took it to the station.
JOSEPH MOUNT (police-constoble C 6.) I produce a certificate of Bryan's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

KENNEDY—
NOT GUILTY .

BRYAN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.

3061.
MICHAEL JONES and
JOSEPH COLLINS were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of Sept., 6 sets of ginders, value 15l.; 6 sets of rotche-wheels, 12l.; 3 regulating wheels, 6l.; 5 screw-boxes, 2l. 10s.; 3 eccen
trics, 9s.; 4 brass fans, 1l.; 1 screw and brass wheel, 2l.; 3 pairs of brass bearings, 10s.; 3 half slides, 1l. 10s.; and 3 swing-handles, 15s.; the goods of
John Carter and another, their masters; to which

JONES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

COLLINS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Months.

3062.
REBECCA BROOKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Oct., 10 yards of printed cotton, value 8s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Deve
rell and another.

SAMUEL HARRIS . I am assistant to Thomas and John Deverell, dra
pers, in Oxford-street. On the 9th of Oct. the prisoner came into the shop, and while the young man turned to reach down some goods that she asked for, I saw her take this print and put under her shawl—I let her go to the door, and told the young man to fetch her back—he did so, and this dress was taken from under her shawl, in the shop.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not have any dealings with her? A. No—she said, "I never intended to steal it."
COURT. Q. Who lifted up her shawl? A. The young man, and I took the print from her.
STEPHEN PADRIAN (police-constable D 16.) I took the prisoner—she said she did not intend to steal it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

3063.
THOMAS WHEELER and
TIMOTHY KEITH were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of Oct., 1 sovereign; the money of
Ann Maria Lyons.

ANN MARIA LYONS . I am a tobacconist. At half-past five o'clock on the 14th of Oct., the prisoners came for a cigar—Keith put down a sovereign, and asked for change—I asked if they had got any change—they both said they had not—I took out my purse, put down a half-sovereign, two half-crowns, four, shillings, two fourpenny-pieces, and took two penny-pieces out of the till—I tried the sovereign; it was a good one, and heavy, a George and dragon one—I got a piece of paper, lit it, and handed it to Wheeler; and while he lighted his cigar, I took up the sovereign, and found it was a counterfeit, and very light—I went round, and accused them of making a mistake—they said, how dare I charge them?—I called my young woman, and she said it was a bad one—I desired her to fetch a policeman—I shot the door—Keith seized my hand and my throat—Wheeler said to him, "Give her the good one, or give me the change"—I heard a something rattling in Keith's mouth—I then found my breath nearly gone, and screamed "Mur
der"—I threw the counterfeit sovereign from me, and it was picked up, and found where I threw it—this is it—I marked it at the station.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How long have you kept this

shop? A. More than a twelvemonth—I am a widow—my husband did not keep a shop—I never take a sovereign up till I have given change—I took it up, looked at it, and drew it a little nearer to me—I have a till, but I always put gold into my purse—I took some of the silver out of my purse at that time, because I had not sufficient in the till—I took the first sovereign, and looked at it—I am sure this is not the same—the first was a good one—I rung that—I did not ring the second—no good sovereign was found on the prisoners that I am aware of.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did they appear a little the worse for drink? A. No, not to me—they were in the shop ten minutes or a quarter of an hour.

JOHN DUNN (police-constable F 46.) I arrived at the shop. The prisoners had hold of Mrs. Lyons—I laid hold of both of them, and told them to pick the sovereign up—they picked it up and gave it to me—I put it into my pocket—I said I must take them to Bow-street—they made a desperate struggle with me in the shop, and the prosecutrix locked the door till we got more assistance—I saw keith swallowing something—there was a lump in his throat.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Is not this shop rather a doubt
ful place? A. Not that I am aware of—I am the policeman on the beat—I have been there a week or two—I called there this morning for the witness—I do not know what is transacted in the house.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You found on Keith a fourpenny
piece? A. Yes, two half-crowns; and four shillings and twopence on Wheeler.

WHEELER*—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

KEITH*—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

3064.
WILLIAM HUMPHREYS was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of Oct., 2 umbrellas, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Howard.

THOMAS HOWARD . On the 3rd of Oct. I put up my chaise, with two um
brellas in it, at the King's Arms, Fulbam—I missed them when I got home—the prisoner was assisting the ostler at the King's Arms.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Had you seen him before? A. No; he put my horse to about eight in the evening—the umbrellas were taken out of my chaise by the ostler, and I found fault with him for it—I was only going to stop a short time—I cannot tell whether they were put back—these are the umbrellas.
JOHN GODFREY . These umbrellas were pawned by the prisoner at Mr. Watts's—this is the duplicate of them.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you certain of him? A. Yes; he came before serving time in the morning, and I noticed him.
LUKE BUTT (police-constable B 47.) I took the prisoner—he put his hand into his waistcoat pocket, and I took this duplicate from him.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

3065.
JOHN ELGER, the younger, was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Sept., 4 carpet bags, value 18s.; the goods of
Edward Smith, his master; and
JOHN ELGER ,
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to be stolen; against the Statute, &c.

EDWARD SMITH . I am a warehouseman in Grocers'-hall-court, Poultry. John Eiger, jun, was in my employ—I had seen his father at my place twice—I had about one hundred carpet bags—on the 3rd of Oct. I missed some—I spoke to John Elger, jun., about them—he denied all knowledge of them—I went to his father's house on the 4th of Oct., and said to him, "This is a

pretty mess John has got into about the carpet bags"—he came down and asked his son if he knew anything about them—he said he did sot—Elger, the father, said that he could lay down his life and his existence that his son was innocent—I have found forty-seven of them—these four are mine.
STEPHEN WHITTAKER . I am a pawnbroker. These four carpet bags were pawned on the 23rd Sept., by John Elger, sen.

WILLIAM MORRELL (police-constabe G 60.) I went to the house—both the prisoners were there—I took them to the station, and charged them with the felony—on the way back to the house, the father said, "It is very hard to accuse an innocent man, I have never seen them"—I was looking about for the duplicates, and the son said, "You need not look, you will find no tioket of the bags, I can tell you"—I did not find any.
John Elger, sen. I have a wife and nine children—I have been for the last eighteen months in utter distress.

JOHN ELGER, jun.—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

JOHN ELGER—
GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Confined Nine Months.
(There were four other indictments against the prisoners.)

3066.
WILLIAM JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Oct., 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Poulton, from his person.

WILLIAM WEST (police-constable T 106.) I was in the hall of the New Court, Old Bailey, about five in the afternoon of the 24th of Oct., waiting to go before the Grand Jury—I watched the prisoner, and saw him take some
thing from a gentleman's pocket, and put it under his jacket—I took this hand
kerchief from under his jacket—I found on him these two other handkerchiefs, and these two knives.

THOMAS POULTON . I am a soda-water manufacturer. I missed my hand
kerchief, and just at that moment West showed it to me—this is it.
Prisoner's Defence. I found it at my feet; I was going out and West took me; I did not know whose it was.

GUILTY .* Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

3067.
MARY CARROLL was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of Oct., 2 gowns, value 1l. 18s.; 3 petticoats, 7s. 6d.; 1 shawl, 15s.; 1 pair of stays, 14s. 6d.; 1 bonnet, 14s. 6d.; 1 pair of boots, 4s. 6d.; 1 collar, 3s. 6d.; and 1 handkerchief, 3s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Daley.

ELIZABETH DALEY . I am an unfortunate girl, and lodged with the pri
soner's mother—on the 6th of Oct. I went to bed, leaving my things all safe—when I got up they were all gone, and the prisoner too—she slept with me—these are all my things—(looking at them.)
ELIZABETH SPREADBURY . I produce the boots, petticoats, and bonnet—I found the prisoner wearing them on the 7th of Oct.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Two Months.

3068.
LOUISA DAVIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; the goods of
Hiram Crisp.

MARY ANN LAWS . I am single. On the 23rd of Oct. I was in Pitfield-street, and saw the prisoner take a pair of shoes in her right hand, and cut them from the prosecutor's door—I went and told the young man, and she was taken back—I saw her give them to another person, who crossed the road and was gone.
GEORGE BURNELL . I am shopman to Hiram Crisp—some shoes hung by the side of the door on the 23rd of Oct.—I missed a pair—I had seen them safe about an hour before.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

3069.
HENRY JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Oct., 2 pewter pots, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
William Coomber; and that he had been before convicted of felony.
WILLIAM COOMBER . I am a licensed victualler, and live in Dorset-street I swear these two pewter pots are mine—the prisoner had no right to take them.

JOHN HADDOCK . I was going down Harley-street last Wednesday even
ing—I saw the prisoner stoop down an area and take a quart pot—he put it into his pocket—he went into the Park, took it out, took a knife out, stooped, and appeared to be cutting it—he then returned, and took two pint pots from an area—I gave information to an officer.

Prisoner. Q. What are you? A. A labourer—I have worked for Mr. Grant, a coachmaker in Hatton-garden—I have been convicted of pot
stealing myself.
WILLIAM JONES (police-constable D 59.) I received information, and took the prisoner—I found on him these three quart pots and these two pints.
Prisoner. Haddock was the person who induced me to do anything of the kind; and he was on this very occasion after the same property; if I had not taken it he would.
JOHN SPIERS (police-constable D 142.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

3070.
MARY RYAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Oct., 1 box, value 3s.; 12 yards of lace, value 1s.; 3 collars, 3s.; 6 ostrich fea
thers, 1s.; and 1 tea-caddy, 2s.; the goods of
Mina Wood.

MINA WOOD . I am single, and live in Queen's-place, Great Queen-street; the prisoner was employed by me. On the 14th of Oct. I found her outside my door—I looked at her very hard—she said, "Don't look at me; I have got nothing belonging to you"—I said, "I did not say that you had"—I sent my ser
vant out for an errand—she came back and said did I give the woman two boxes—I went after the prisoner, and found her with two boxes under her apron—I asked her what she had got, she said, "Nothing"—these are them—she had no right to them—I had placed them under my bed.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. What was she employed as? A. A charwoman—she had got about eleven yards from my door—I keep a lodging-house—I do not inquire what my lodgers' friends are—I do not know what my lodgers do—mine is not a house of ill-fame.
JURY. Q. Who admitted her into the house? A. There is a latch and a handle, which must be turned—I am quite sure my door was shut
THOMAS TICKNER (police-constable F 11.) I took the prisoner at the prosecutrix's house.
Cross-examined. Q. The boxes were in the house? A. Yes, all the prisoner said was, "You are quite mistaken"—I know nothing about the house, it is not on my beat.

MARY HEIFY . I went out on an errand, and met the prisoner coming out with two boxes—I asked her if she had seen my mistress—she said, "Yes, it is all right"—I had cleared the room before, and saw the box under the bed.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Six Months.

3071.
GEORGE RICHARDS, alias Ritchie
, and
WILLIAM CHRIS
TIE were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of Oct., at
St. Marylebone, 12 forks, value 8l.; and 12 spoons, 12l.; the goods of
Thomas Todd Mardon, the master of Christie, in his dwelling-house; and that Richards had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY BROOK . I am footman, in the service of Mr. Thomas Todd Mardon, of Wirapole-street, Cavendish-square—Christie has been butler then for ten years—he had the care of the plate—it had been put away for some time—in August last it was taken out, counted, found right, and given again into the care of Christie—he had the key of the boxes—Ri
chards has been in the habit of coming to my master's, to see Christie, and came sometimes when we had parties, with my master's knowledge. On the 6th of Oct., about half-past eleven, or a quarter to twelve o'clock in the day, as I went out on an errand, I passed the butler's pantry—Richards and Christie were in it—in about a quarter of an hour I returned, and met Richards at the corner of Wimpole-street, coming in a direction from the house—I went in, and saw Christie there—he went out soon after, and did not return any more—the next day a policeman came—the plate chest was opened, and a dozen table-spoons, and two dozen table-forks, were missed from it—in looking about afterwards, I found some duplicates—I gave them to the policeman—these are my master's spoons and forks, and have the family crest on them.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You have been some time in the service? A. Eighteen months—I never took anything out of pawn daring that time—I had forgotten, I did take a pair of my master's boots out—I did not give them to Richards—he did not tend me for them—that was between three and four months ago—the butler said it was my duty to go.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Was your master in the habit during the summer-time of going to the sea-side? A. He did not this year—he did last, and during that time the whole of the plate was left in Christie's care—it is worth a great deal.

JOHN BOOKER . I manage the business of Mr. Neal, a pawnbroker, in Duke-street, Manchester-square. On the 6th of Oct.
