Richards came to the shop, a little after twelve o'clock—he brought twelve table-spoons and twelve forks, and wanted to pledge them for 16l.—I questioned him—he said they were his own, and his own crest was on them—after that he said it was his father's crest—I looked at it, and said I should go with him—we went out together—he said he lived in Queen-street—when we came out, he went towards Manchester-square—he did not go by a direct road—he took me to a public-house, and wanted me to go into the parlour—I declined it—at last we got to High-street, Marylebone, and then to Wimpole-street—we met a per
son coming up the prosecutor's area steps—he asked some questions, and then we went on to the end of the street, and saw a policeman, who took him.

JOSEPH NIFTON (police-constable D 118.) I was in Mr. Neal's shop this day—I followed Booker and the prisoner when they came out—after follow
ing them up and down the streets, I took Richards, and took him to the station—I went to Mr. Mardon's house in Wimpole-street next day—the box was opened, and this plate was missing.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you search Richards? A. Yes—I found on him a little money.

JOHN STANLEY (police-constable D 48.) I was at Marylebone police station when Christie came there, on Wednesday, the 25th of October—he said, "My name is Christie"—I said, "You come from Wimpole-street?"—he said, "Yes, my attorney will be here at one o'clock"—he said, "I come to sur
render myself for the concern in Wimpole-street."

JAMES FELL . I am clerk at the police court. I was present when Christie was examined—he made a statement, which was read over to him—this is it—( read)—"I wish to speak the truth: I have lived at Mr. Mardon's the last ten years, and found him a very good, kind matter—up to last August I

always conducted myself in a proper way, and never thought of doing anything wrong, until last August, when I engaged George Richards to assist me in clean
ing the furniture; while up stairs with him, I was called by the housemaid to show me that the wardrobe doors had burst open; I then looked into it, and saw a small portmanteau and a bunch of keys; I unfortunately opened it, before the housemaid and Richards; after that I shut the wardrobe, and went down to clean the furniture, and while with Richards, cleaning the furniture, we commenced talking to each other; but previous to that, I told him I was in arrears of rent, and several other little bills, and he told me I need not be in want for no money, for he would go and pledge these things for me; so, in the course of two or three days after, I unfortunately let him go with part of the plate, and then, some days after that, we went with some more of it; when that plate that belonged to the portmanteau was pledged, I began to feel very uncomfortable and uneasy in my own mind, and I told Richards so; then he advised me take some of the plate that was under my care, to take out what belonged to the portmanteau, and I did so, with the intent of taking them out again; I have given myself up, with the expectation of Mr. Mardon and the Court showing me mercy."
(Christie received a good character.)

CHARLES FOX . I produce a certificate of Richards's former conviction which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person—I was not pre
sent at his trial—I was in Court when sentence was passed against him.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Was he sentenced by himself or with others? A. With ten or a dozen others—it was for a robbery at the Travellers' Club, in which service I was—I think the late Recorder sentenced him—I saw him going from the bar, and he shook his head at me.

CHRISTIE—
GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

RICHARDS—
GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Transported for Ten Years.

3072.
GEORGE HENRY HAISELL was indicted
for forging and utter
ing, on the 20th of Feb., a certain bill of exchange for the payment of the sum of 37l. 12s., with intent to defraud
Elizabeth Hatton.

THOMAS CHARLES SIRRELL . I am a gold-refiner, and live in Barbican. The prisoner frequently called on me—I could not undertake to say he brought this bill with him, as he was in the habit of coming himself, and of sending a young man who is since dead—I discounted this bill (looking at it) a day or two after it was drawn—I could not undertake to say whether I paid the money to the prisoner, or to the person be sent the bill by, but it was on the faith of his note from the firm, on the faith that he had authority from the firm to draw it—if the prisoner did not bring it, a person named Woolley did—this is my signature to these depositions—(looking at them)—this bill, marked No. 1, is for 37l. 12s.—it purports to be drawn by procuration of Elizabeth Hatton and Co.—I discounted it—I do not remember the day, except by the bill-book—I would not undertake to say that the prisoner brought me this bill—he brought me one bill, and two were brought to me by Woolley, to the best of my recollection and belief—I never said that to the best of my belief it was the prisoner—I could not say whether it was No. 1, 2, or 3, he brought.

ELIZABETH HATTON . I carry on the business of a chemist and Prussian
blue maker, in Elder-street, Spitalfields—it was formerly the business of my son—he has been dead three years. In Feb. last the prisoner was in my ser
vice, at a salary of 150l. a-year—he had no authority from me to draw bills

by procuration in my name—he was not in any way interested in the affairs of my business, except by payment of his salary—I did not give him autho
rity in Feb., or at any time, to draw this bill, or any other, by procuration—I first knew there was such a bill five or six weeks ago from the gentleman who held it—I have never received any proceeds for this bill, either in money or in money's worth.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe your concern sustained con
siderable loss just before your son's death? A. It might—I never was in
formed of a loss of 1200l.—it never was suggested together—I have occa
sionally drawn on my customers for their accounts, I cannot say how many times since my son's death, but then I endorsed them—my name went to them—the prisoner presented the bills to me, and came for my acceptance, for me to put "E. Hatton and Co." on them—I never authorized him to draw a bill by procuration, nor ever authorised it to be done, I am quite sure—he had the management of this concern—I lived at a distance, but occasionally came there on business—the money was generally sent to me at the end of the week by some one from the factory, or the prisoner brought it himself—the endorsement, "E. Hatton," on this bill—(looking at one)—is in my hand
writing—this other endorsement is also in my writing—this other one is also, and so is this one—(these were all drawn by procuration by the prisoner)—this cheque on my bankers is in my handwriting—this signature, "E. Hatton," to this letter, is in my handwriting.

Q. Did the prisoner ever draw bills in his own name, for the purpose of carrying on the concern; I mean bills drawn by himself, without mentioning your name at all, in order that he might raise money by discounting these bills? A. Not till lately—he has done so lately, as I have been given to un
derstand—this is my acceptance to this bill drawn by the prisoner in his own name on the firm—this other one is mine—I did not give him unlimited au
thority to raise money in any way he thought best, for the purpose of carrying on the business, not without my knowledge—I have no recollection of having sworn before the Magistrate, that, except in one instance where I accepted a bill drawn by the prisoner for 50l., which was for his own salary, I never accepted a bill in my life drawn by him—I never knew of any others but what my hand went to—I never told the Magistrate that I never accepted a bill drawn by the prisoner, except that one for 50l. for his salary—I acknow
ledged there were several other bills, but not by procuration—I never accepted any bill drawn by the prisoner in his own name without I put my hand to it. Q. I wish you would give me an answer; I want to understand what it is you are prepared to swear; do you mean to deny that you told the Magistrate that you had never accepted a bill drawn by the prisoner oh the firm, except the one for 50l. for salary? A. I certainly did not say it; not by procuration, the bills are so different—I do not know anything of other bills.

Q. I am speaking of bills drawn by your own clerk, and accepted by you, to get money to carry on the business by? A. I acknowledge there were three bills of this kind before the Magistrate, of Mr. Sirrell's—they were the first that I saw.
Q. Do you mean to say now, on your oath, that those that I have shown you to-day, which have your own handwriting on them, were not seen by you before? A. Of course they were.
Q. What did you mean by saying, till you saw these three, you had no idea that he had ever drawn a bill by procuration on your house? A. I never was aware of it.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you ever authorize, or were you ever aware that

the prisoner had drawn, accepted, or issued any bill of exchange for any pur
pose, except that to which, as drawer, indorser, or acceptor, you had put your name? A. No.

Q. Look at this bill, which is drawn "Value received. P. P. E. Hatton and Co. G. H. Haisell." Look at the signature to the bill? A. This "Hatton and Company" is not mine—I see "P. P. E. Hatton and Company. G. H. Haisell—I do not know what this "P. P." means.
(MR. CLARKSON here withdrew from the prosecution.)
(There were three other indictments, on which no evidence was offered.)
NOT GUILTY .

3073.
CHARLES BLACK was indicted
for embezzling 3s. 1d., the monies of his master,
James Trunk: also,
for obtaining money by false pretences; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

3074.
SAMUEL FULLBROOK was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

PETER HAYNES . I live in Oxford-street, Commercial-road. I am the father of William Haynes, who is committed for the murder of his wife—the Jury sat on her body—the prisoner came to my house, and wished to see the body, because, he said, he was one of the Jury—I let him do so—he then asked me for some vinegar to wash his hands, and asked when I intended to bury it—I said the next day—he said, "Where?"—I said, "At Haggerston church"—he said, "I am the parish clerk"—I said, "Perhaps you will be so kind as to take the warrant for interment, and see to the grave"—he said he would, and said, "There are dues fot the interment"—I said, "Very well, what are they?"—he said, "18s. 6d.," which I gave him for the dues—when I began to reflect in the evening, I thought I had been deceived, and waited on the person who I found to be the parish clerk the next morning—I should not have given the prisoner that 18s. 6d. if he had not told me he was the clerk—if I had not believed it I should not have given it him—I did not per
ceive that he was drunk.

SAMUEL ROUSE . I am parish clerk of St. Mary, Haggerston; I have been there four years. The prisoner has never acted as parish clerk while I have been there—he had no authority to take any money for burials or anything.
Prisoner. I had been drinking in the morning.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Nine Months.

3075.
MICHAEL DUNN was indicted
for assaulting
Jesse Lawrence, a police officer, in the execution of his duty.

BAKER—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.

3076.
WILLIAM COOPER was indicted
for unlawfully breaking and entering the shop of
William Shrub, with intent to steal.

WILLIAM SHRUB (police-constable D 49.) About ten minutes past three o'clock in the morning of the 4th of Oct. I heard a smash of glass—I looked, and saw the prisoner standing with his back to me, and his arm through a pane of glass that was broken in the shop window—he pulled out his arm, and ran off—I pursued—he was secured without ray losing sight of him—I swear his arm was through the window.

CHARLES HALL . I am a watchmaker. I left my shop, in the Edgware-road, safe on the 3rd of Oct., fastened with a bar and four shutters—I came the next morning, a shutter was then down, and the glass was broken—there were watches, clocks, and other property in the shop.
JAMES CREEK (police-constable D 94.) I stopped the prisoner—I found these four keys in his pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. Does it stand feasible that I could take a shutter down from a strong iron bar?

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

3077.
MARIA BROWN was indicted
for obtaining money under false pretences.

WILLIAM THOMAS LYON . The prisoner was in my service two years—she had to pay several sums, such as milk, bread, and little things for the house—these are the papers of them—they are merely memorandums, and have no dates, because I considered they were done with; but I found that bills were brought in by my baker and milk-man to the amount of some pounds, when I did not consider that I owed any thing—on the 19th of May, I paid her 1s. 4 1/4 d. for the baker, Richard Gullins—I am sure she came to me for that sum for him, and I paid it—I also paid her 6d. for milk for Richard Stukeley, the told me she wanted the money for him, and I gave it her—she brought me the bills of them, as an account of the money she had expended.
RICHARD GULLINS . I did not receive of the prisoner 1s. 4 1/4 d. on the 19th of May—the money is still due.
THOMAS BYTHAN . I live with Mr. Stukeley—I did not receive anything of the prisoner on the 19th of May—the money is still due.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

3078.
GEORGE CHAPMAN and
MATTHEW HODGSON were in
dicted for
obtaining money by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
3079.
JAMES PENDLETON and
OLIVER MARTIN were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th Oct., at
St. George, Bloomsbury, 2 watches, value 7l. 14s.; 1 guard-chain, 16s.; 2 spoons, 1l. 10s.; 2 sovereigns, 7 half-sove
reigns, 1 crown, 10 half-crowns, 40 shillings, 30 sixpences, and 60 groats; the property of
James Smith, in his dwelling-house.

SOPHIA SMITH . I am the wife of James Smith, publican, Kinggate-street, Holborn—on the 12th of October I went into my bed-room, which is the front room, second floor, and put two sovereigns, a crown piece, two half-crowns, and seven shillings, into a drawer—there were two spoons and a watch of my husband's in it—I locked it—a tea-caddy was standing on the drawers—my watch was in the caddy—I left the room between twelve and one in the day, locked the door, and hung the key on a nail in the bar parlour—the pri
soners had been customers—as I was coming down stairs, I saw the prisoners and another man not in custody, in the bagatelle-room, which is on the first floor—they were standing by the board—one had the mace in his hand, and the other was sitting down—I had seen the third man there before in the prisoners' company two or three times—about half-past one the prisoners came from up stairs, and passed through the bar parlour, the bar, and the passage, and went out—they asked for some gin—I was at dinner, and my husband served them—they were all three together—they paid their reckon
ing and went away—I dined in the bar parlour, which commands a view of the bar—no one had been up after I came down—about four I went into my bed-room and found the drawer and tea-caddy broken open, and the money, watches, and spoons gone—the lock of the door was picked, but not injured in the least—it could not have been opened by my key, because I had it down stairs—there is no other way of going into the bagatelle-room, and to my bed-room, but through the bar parlour—I can undertake to say, that no one had

gone up those stairs from the time I came down and hung up the key, till my husband went up after the prisoners had gone—I had no servant—I have two lodgers up stairs, but they went out at nine o'clock, and did not return till the evening.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. What are your lodgers? A. One has been a publican—he had only left his business about a week, and was looking out for another; the other one is in some trade, I do not know what—the house contains eleven rooms—it is not sometimes frequented by sport
ing characters—we have card-playing sometimes—I do not remember my hus
band losing at cards a few days before this, and having to go up stairs to get money to pay for it; if he had, he would have asked me, because I had the key of the drawer where the money was—I cannot say whether I had it two days before—two of our rooms are unoccupied—one is a bagatelle-room, one a spirit room, one a kitchen, and the others spare rooms—if a per
son came for a lodging he would have had one of these rooms—one of them was occupied a week before, the other was not—our house is pretty well at
tended of an evening sometimes—I do not recollect any card-playing in our house an evening or two before—I do not know two men named Mason and Crook—I might know the men—I do not remember a man they call the Brewer's Collector playing at cards—I was there when he came in on Wed
nesday evening, and he did not stay more than twenty minutes—I think there were one or two playing at cards—I did not hear a bet of ten crowns to one—I do not know whether they were playing for money—there is a water-closet just as you get outside the parlour door, adjoining the stairs.
MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see the men go away that were playing at cards? A. Yes—I am sure they left the house, and the collector too—that was the day before this.

JAMES SMITH . I keep this public-house. Between twelve and one o'clock this day, I saw the prisoners and another man at our house—I had seen them in company several times before—Pendleton and the other man came in company on this day—Martin came in soon after, and asked if his friends were there—he walked up stairs into the bagatelle room—my wife was up stairs in the bed room—before Martin came in Pendleton ordered a glass of gin and water—I went up stairs, and saw him and the other man there when I took it up—I came down stairs, and in the course of a minute Martin came in—I afterwards saw them altogether up stairs in the bagatelle room—I was not absent from the bar more than a minute, when I took up the gin and water—while I was gone I let the flap of my bar down, and shut the door, so that no one could have gone up stairs while I was there without my meeting them—no one was up stairs but my wife to my knowledge—she came down in ten minutes, or a quarter of an hour—she came into the bar where I was—I did not leave the bar, except when I went up with the gin and water, unless my wife was there—I remember the pri
soner and the third man coming down stairs—they had something to drink at the bar, paid for what they had up stairs, and left—while we were at din
ner, no one came in to go up stairs, till the prisoners went away—if they had I must have seen them, as they must have passed through the bar and the bar parlour—no one went out after the prisoners—I went up stairs about four o'clock, with the key of the bed-room, which I took from the bar par
lour—I found the lock had been picked—the lock had not gone quite back—the drawer had been rifled, and the property in the tea-caddy was gone—the money that was gone was about 10l.—on the Saturday night after, I was in Fleet-street, and saw the prisoners with several others—I ran to the officers who were before me, and Restieaux took Pendleton—Martin started off,
ran through Fleet-street, and through the Temple—he then fell down, and was taken.

Cross-examined. Q. Don't you know that a night or two before Martin had given a man a good thrashing, and he had got a summons out for him? A. No—I was close to him when he was taken—the officer said, "I want you for a robbery in Kingsgate-street"—I did not hear Martin say, "On, that is it, I was just going up there for a box of cigars on which I paid 1s. 6d."—he had paid 1s. 6d. there—I might have played at cards a night or two before the robbery—I had to go up stairs for money to pay my losings, but not with the prisoners, they were persons who have used the house these four years—respectable men—I cannot say what I lost.

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX (police-constable E 49.) On the 14th of Oct. I was with the prosecutor, and his brother in Fleet-street—I saw the prisoners—I secured Pendleton—he said he knew nothing about it, but he had played at bagatelle there with a friend of his.
JOHN JAMES ALLEN (police-constable E 159.) I was with the prosecutor in Fleet-street—I saw Mason run away—I followed him through the Temple—he fell down, and I secured him.
NOT GUILTY .

3080.
ELIZABETH COOK was indicted
for concealing the birth of her child; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Two Months.

3081.
JOHN DANIELS was indicted
for indecently exposing his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined One Month.

3082.
REBECCA ARCHER was indicted
for bigamy.
WILLIAM DREDGE . I married the prisoner at Wellington, about twelve years ago last May—I have a certificate of the marriage.
RALPH SIMPSON . I am a butcher, and live at Horncburch. In 1824, I saw the prisoner married to John Archer, who is in Court—she had sworn herself with child by him—I was a constable at the time.
JOHN CLAPSON (policeman.) I apprehended the prisoner at Barking.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know my first husband was alive, as he had left me seventeen years; I was informed he was dead two years after he left me.

WILLIAM DREDGE
re-examined. I heard nothing of Archer till two or three months ago, and did not know whether he was alive or dead.
NOT GUILTY .

3083.
GEORGE SLENNET was indicted
for feloniously killing and slay
ing
William Beech.

WILLIAM BEECH . I am a shoemaker, and live in Angel-lane, Stratford. The deceased William Beech was my son—on the 16th of Aug., near eight o'clock in the evening, I was in the marshes, near Temple mills, and saw the prisoner second Charles Gilson, in fighting with my son—I do not know how it began—they had had a fight the day before, and also that morning—when

I first saw them in the evening, they were going down the marshes, and a great many people with them, to see them fight—I followed—I tried to pre
vent their fighting in the morning, and so I did in the evening, but could not—my son was past my jurisdiction—he told me if he did not fight, he should be called a coward—he was turned twenty years of age—I saw them fighting, and saw my son get weak—Slennet said to Gilson, "Now is your time; give it him; follow him up"—after that, Gilson hit him on the side of the head, knocked him down, and fell on him—my son became stupid, and did not speak any more—he only groaned—he died at half-past eleven o'clock at night.

Prisoner. Q. Did not he say, after he fell, "You have beat me to-night, and the next time I meet you, I shall serve you the same as you have served me to-night." A. I did not hear him—I did not go into the ring and back my son—I kept along with the people, alongside where they were fighting—I did not say, "My boy shan't be beaten by a boy like that."
JOHN BAILEY . I am a cordwainer. I saw the fight in the morning, but not in the evening—I saw nothing of the prisoner.

CHARLES HOWELL . I am a surgeon, and live at Stratford. I saw the de
ceased about half-past ten o'clock on the 16th of Aug.—he was quite insen
sible, and breathing with great difficulty—I bled him, but it did not relieve him—he died about three quarters of an hour after—his death was caused by extravasated blood on the brain—I opened the head thirty-six hours after the death—there was a blow externally on the left side of the head—it seemed a violent blow, and in my judgment was the cause of his death.

JAMES DYSON . I saw the fight, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening. The prisoner was taking part in it; at least I think it was him; but there are two brothers, so alike, that I could not swear it was him—the parties were quite agreeable to fight, and there was nothing unfair in it—it did not last longer than ten or fifteen minutes—I think the injury the de
ceased received was principally through falls—there were not many very severe blows—he had a very severe fall or two backwards, in the struggle, and he fell undermost.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not go with any intention to second the young man. His brother picked him up three rounds; he then took his clothes, and said to me, "George, I wish you would have the kindness to pick my brother up:" I said I would, and did so.
NOT GUILTY .

3084.
JAMES BURRELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Sept., 1 watch, value 1l. 10s., the property of
Edward Richardson.

EDWARD RICHARDSON . I live at the Checkers public-house at Waltham
stow. I had a watch safe on the 28th of Sept., in the knife-house—I missed it on the 29th—this is my watch, and the one I lost.
JOSEPH KITCHING . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this watch, pawned by the prisoner on the 28th of Sept.—I am sure he is the man.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about it.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Four Months.

3085.
JOSEPH PAGE was indicted
for attempting to commit a detest
able crime.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.

3086.
JAMES COOPER was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Sept., 1 handkerchief, value 2d.; the goods of
William Thornton, from hit person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Year.

3087.
CHARLES CROMBIE was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Aug., 2 50l. Bank-notes; the property of
Elizabeth Lavallin, in the dwelling-house of
James Cucksey.

ELIZABETH LAVALLIN . I am a widow, and live in Upper George-street, Greenwich. The prisoner lodged there wfth me and my daughter, whom he married—I went to London, and received the portion of some property which came to me—I had two 50l. and three 5l. Bank-notes—I returned—he knew I had received the money—I did not tell him where I put it—I put it in a bag, into a closet, and saw it safe about nine o'clock in the morn
ing of the 16th of Aug.—the key was left in the lock of the closet-door—I went to the closet about six o'clock, and missed the money—the prisoner had left then—he said a person named Leicester had sent to him to attend a funeral at Deptford; he was to be there at half-past two o'clock, and should return in time to take the baby to her mother, who war nursing at a gentle
man's house—he never returned—my son Henry bad taken the numbers of the notes, and he gave them to the police-inspector—I saw my son take the numbers.

Prisoner. You had no home, and were with me twelve or eighteen months, and only gave roe 3l. or 4l. the whole time. Witness. I deny it—I took cars of the child, and my daughter Louisa worked at her sister's business—I have paid you 10l. for rent.
HENRY LAVALLIN . I live at Mr. Ender's rope-manufactory, Greenwich. On the 15th I saw my mother receive the money—I took the numbers of the notes as soon as we returned home—I gave her the paper.

EDWARD FREEMAN . I am inspector of the Greenwich police. On the 16th of Aug. I received information of this robbery, and the numbers of the notes—the two 50l. were 07924 and 07925, the 5l., 78662, 63, and 64.
THOMAS WHITMORE . I am a clerk in the Bank of England. On the 16th of Aug. a person came to the Bank, and received payment of this 50l. note, No. 07924—the name of Lavallin is written on it.
MRS. LAVALLIN. I believe this name to be the prisoner's handwriting.

JOHN HAWKES . I am pay-clerk in the Bank of England. This 50l. note, No. 07924, was paid on the 16th of Aug., by a person giving the name of Lavallin—I gave five 10l. notes for it—two of them were Not. 55267 and 55269, dated 10th June, 1843.
ALEXANDER ROBERTSON . I am pay-clerk at the Bank. On the 16th of Aug., between two and four o'clock, I paid a person fifty sovereigns for this 50l. note, No. 07925.

EDWARD PITT YOUELL . I am clerk at a banking-house at Yarmouth. On the 25th of Aug. the prisoner deposited 65l. at our bank, in the name of Arthur Wensley, as I understood him—I received from him two 10l. notes, Nos. 55267 and 69, dated 10th June, 1848, and two 5l. notes, Nos. 78662 and 64, the rest in gold—he took 10l. out on the 26th, and the rest on the 29th.

CHARLES STURGE FLETCHER . I am inspector of police at Cambridge. On the 26th of Oct. I found the prisoner at a house at Cambridge, and told him I took him on suspicion of stealing Bank notes from Mrs. Lavallin, of Greenwich—he said he knew nothing of Greenwich, and I was deceived; he was not the person, his name was Arthur Wellesley, and he came from London—I found a box and bag there—I asked if they were his—he said, "Yes"-—I found bills of parcels amounting to 46l., and a gold watch in it—I asked him to write his name—he wrote "Arthur Wellesley, K. G. C., London," and said he was the son of the Duke of Wellington; and while in custody he wrote a letter to the Duke, begging His Grace to write a letter, that he might be released.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know what I was doing; I had entirely lost my senses for some hours.

GUILTY of Larceny only. Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3088.
THOMAS THORN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Dec., at
Woolwich, 1 watch, value 5l.; 1 guard, 1s.; and 1 key, 6d.; the good of
William Daniels, his master, in his dwelling-house.

MARY ANN DANIELS . I am the wife of William Daniels, and keep a public-house at Woolwich. On the 26th of Sept. I put my gold watch into the glass drawer on the table—I missed it about half-past two o'clock the same after
noon—this is it—the prisoner was there, helping to wait.

Prisoner. I was not a servant in the house, I was discharged the day be
fore. Witness. I am sure he was in the house that day—he cleaned the pots.

THOMAS MARSON . I am a pawnbroker. I produce the watch which I re
ceived in pledge of the prisoner on the 26th of Sept.
Prisoner. Q. What dress had I on? A. A white moleskin dress, but no jacket—it was between four and five o'clock in the afternoon—I swear you are the person.

Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the watch, nor ever had it in my posses
sion. There was a man drinking in the house that day, dressed very much like me; I was at Woolwich all the day.

p.rs: GUILTY of Larceny only. Aged 34.—Recommended to mercy.

div1.p:
3089.
WILLIAM FOSTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Oct., 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 2 shillings, the property of
John Tester.

CAROLINE TESTER . I am the wife of John Tester. On the 20th of Oct., a few minutes before ten o'clock, I was going by the Observatory, on Wool
wich Common—I had a basket, containing a handkerchief and 2s., which I left at the gate, in the prisoner's care—I came back in about an hour and a half, and all the soldiers were gone—I saw my basket, but the handkerchief and 2s. were gone—I am sure it was in it when I gave it to him.
JOHN WARD . I am a bombardier, in the Royal Artillery. On the 20th of Oct., between twelve and one o'clock, I searched the prisoner's bed, and found this handkerchief—I found 1s. 7 1/2 d. on him.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman.) I took the prisoner—he said he could not imagine what possessed him to do it, he wished he had never seen it—I had cautioned him that whatever he said I should be obliged to use against him.

CAROLINE TESTER
re-examined. This is my handkerchief.

GUILTY .* Aged 42.—
Confined Three Months.

3090.
WILLIAM COCHRANE was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Oct., 1 purse, value 1d.; 3 sovereign, 17 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the property of
George Brown, from his person.

GEORGE BROWN . I am master of the Harriet coal-brig, and live at Poole, in Dorsetshire—I formerly knew the prisoner at Gibraltar. On Tuesday afternoon, the 10th of Oct., I met him, and went with him to several houses—we went into the Nile tavern—while there I took but my purse which con
tained three sovereigns, eighteen shillings, and two sixpences, to pay for something—the prisoner could see me do that—I put my purse into my pocket again—the prisoner remained four or five minutes after that, and then went out—I was not sober—he had called for a pot of beer——he had drunk a part of it—three or four minutes after he was gone, some soldiers came in, and said the boat was ready—I said, "Call for a pot of beer, and I will pay for it "—I put my hand into my pocket, and the purse was gone.

Prisoner. Q. Were you not in company with some bad women, drinking? A. No, I was three or four hours in your company—I was not in company, or drinking with any woman—I did not see you in the boat, and bid you good night—I was not carried to the boat—I never went near the boat.

EDWARD RICHARDSON . I am mate of the Harriet. On the 10th of Oct. I was in the Nile tavern, and saw the prosecutor and prisoner there—the pro
secutor took out his purse, and put it into his pocket again—there was gold and silver in it—I afterwards saw the prisoner with one arm over the prose
cutor's neck, and the other on the table—he was sitting at the right hand side of the prosecutor, and his hand was towards the right pocket which the purse was in—the prisoner remained a very few minutes after, and had hardly got out of the door when the prosecutor missed his money.

Prisoner. Q. At the time you first saw me, was any one else in company with the prosecutor? A. Yes, two or three of the ship's company, and it was in a house where several girls were drinking, but that was not in the house where the robbery took place—as soon as I came into the house, you took him from there to another house, and when I found him again, you got him from me again, and took him to another house—the prosecutor and you were sitting by your two selves at the time of the robbery—no one but you were with him, from the time he put the purse into his pocket till he missed it.

CAROLINE WEST . I am the wife of John West, who keeps the Marquis of Granby, at Woolwich. About a week or fortnight ago the prisoner came into our house a little after ten o'clock at night, and left two sovereigns with me—he came a little after six next morning with a soldier and two girls, and I returned him the money.

ROBERT COOK . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery, at Woolwich. On the 11th of Oct. I saw the prisoner in the guard-room, with a box nod some tobacco, and silver in it—he put it up the fire-place, and said there was to
bacco, if any one wished to use it.

WILLIAM TWYMAN (police-constable R 127.) I apprehended the prisoner. I examined this chimney, and found this tobacco-box and 11s. in silver in it—I shook the tobacco, and a sovereign fell out from between it—the prisoner said, "I know nothing of it, it is not mine"—he said that directly I found the box, before I examined it.

(The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutor was in company with several bad women, and was very drunk; that he helped to carry him to his boat, and left him; and the money found in his possession was given him by his father.)
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 29.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Month.

3091.
WILLIAM DAVIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Sept., 1 pig, price 30s., the goods of
Thomas Hoskins; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

3092.
JOHN HAYES was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of September, 1 work-box, value 20s., the goods of
Sarah Mahon; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Six Months.

3093.
CHARLES WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Sept., 1 pair of boots, value 6s., the goods of
Robert Kersey; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Two Months.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

3094.
WILLIAM WALKINGHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Oct., 1 pair of boots, value 9s., the goods of
Richard Killick which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

3095.
THOMAS TURNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Oct., 2 1/2 lbs. weight of mutton, value 8d., the goods of
George Longford.

JAMES SUTTON . I am a butcher, and live at Deptford. The prisoner came to the shop on the 17th of Oct., and took up a piece of mutton—he got a considerable distance with it—I took it from him—it belonged to George Longford.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

3096.
GEORGE SMITH was indicted
for a fraud.

BENJAMIN GAWTHORPE . I keep the Duke of York public-house at Dept
ford. On the 9th of Oct. the prisoner came, and said he was a contractor, under Grisell and Peto, for the extension of the railway, that he had got thirty-five men under him, and asked me to let him have beer for the men, and he would pay me weekly—I believed that, and let him have six gallons that evening—he took it to the work, as he said—his wife took some, and he took some—I went the next morning, and found him at work at a different place, and gave him in charge.

Prisoner. I was drunk. Witness. You was not drunk at all—I found out about eleven o'clock the next day that you was not Grisell and Peto's gangs
man—I let six gallons of beer go after I found you did not work for them, but that was because you should not go away till I could get a policeman.
JOHN EMMERTON . I am in the employ of Grisell and Peto. I have no knowledge of the prisoner—he had not thirty-five men at work under him for them, nor was he employed himself.

Prisoner. We should have gathered the money on Saturday night, and have paid him; I did not say I was a contractor; I applied for a supply of beer for myself and others, and to settle for it on Saturday night.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Three Months.

3097.
JOHN RAINSFORTH was indicted
for stealing on the 5th of Sept., 1 coat, value 15s.; and 1 cloak, 10s.; the goods of
Henry Woodgate, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

3098.
RICHARD TRENT,
CAROLINE MALLABONE , and
JAMES KINO , were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
James White, on the 11th of Oct., putting him ia fear, and taking from his person, and against hit will, 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns, and 15l. note; his property; and feloniously beating, striking, and using other personal violenoe to him.

JAMES WHITE . I am a carpenter, and live in Russell-row, Locks-fields. On Tuesday, the 11th of Oct., as I was coming up the Walworth-rood, about a quarter past one o'clock at night, going home, some parties came behind me, and gave me a push on the neck, which threw me down—as soon as I was down, Trent's hands were in my right hand trowsers' pocket, and across my breast—I cried out, "Keep your hands out of my pocket"—I had scarcely spoken the words before a policeman came up, and made a grab at Trent, who instantly ran away—the policeman pursued him, sprang his rattle, and he was stopped by a constable by the Elephant and Castle—I found that I had lost my pocket-book, a 5l. note, and two sovereigns—the note was in the pocket-book, in my breast pocket, and the sovereigns in my right hand trowsers' pocket—I had felt the book safe about two minutes before—I only saw Trent—it happened dose by a gas-light.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Has anything of this kind hap
pened to you before? A. Yes—I have been robbed three times, some years ago—I was the worse for liquor, but was perfectly capable of taking care of myself—I had been out in the day on business, and had refreshment at two places—the last place was the Alfred's Head—I had not been there more than a quarter of an hour—I had felt my pocket-book safe two minutes before this occurred, by putting my hand outside my coat pocket, and about three minutes before that I doubled down the top part of the paper, because It was too long for the depth of the pocket, to keep it out of sight—I had four sove
reigns in my left hand pocket, which were not taken—I did not fall down from being tipsy—I was pushed down from behind—I saw no one but Treat—he was not assisting to raise me up in consequence of the helpless state I was in—I swear he did not try to raise me up at all—I had been to the Alfred's Head with a man who sells mahogany—there might be some women there—I did not see any girls of the town—I was not treating or drinking with any—I saw the prisoners searched—nothing was found on them.

WILLIAM JENNINGS (police-constable P 95.) On the 11th of Oct. I was on duty in the Walworth-road, coming out of Union-court, leading into the main road, and saw the prosecutor and prisoners pass along nearly in a line together—King stepped into Union-court—I asked what he did there—he said, "I have not done anything"—about a minute afterwards I heard a fall on the pavement just outside the court—I stepped out, and saw the prosecu
tor lying on the pavement, and Trent leaning over him, with his left hand over his breast, and his right hand was drawing from his right-hand trowsers' pocket—the prosecutor said, "You have robbed me of my pocket-book and a 5l. note"—I made a reach at Trent, and also at the female prisoner, who was standing about a yard from the prosecutor—Trent started off—I followed him, crying, "Stop thief," and sprang my rattle—he was stopped by a police
man
of the L division, without my losing sight of him, at the corner of St. George's-road, by the Elephant and Castle, about 100 yards from where he started—I did not see what became of Mallabone.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not see the commencement of this transaction? A. No—the prosecutor was lying about two yards from the entrance of the court—when I first saw King he was in the court—I was coming out of the court when King turned in—I did not see King do anything—he was not five yards from the prosecutor—I went into the road on hearing the prosecu
tor fall down—he was in liquor—Trent was not laying hold of him to raise him up.

ALFRED WILLIAM WAKEFIELD (police-constable L 117.) About one o'clock in the morning I saw the prosecutor pass by, and the three prisoners walking and talking together, about three or four yards behind him—I lost sight of them for about ten minutes—I afterwards heard a rattle, and saw Trent run
ning from the Walworth-road towards St. George's-road, and Jennings after him—I slopped him, and took him into custody—I took Mallabone between eleven and twelve next day, and King between two and three in the afternoon—I searched them all, but found nothing on either of them.
NOT GUILTY .

3099.
JOHN ROBINSON was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of Oct., 2 waistcoats, value 15s.; 1 3/4 yard of fustian, 1s. 9d.; the goods of
Thomas Nickenson; and that he had been before convicted of felony: and
ESTHER CLEMENTS
, for feloniously receiving the said ustian, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

THOMAS NICKENSON . I am a tailor, and live in Battersea-square. I saw these waistcoats and fustian safe on the 9th of Oct., and missed them on the 10th—I cannot swear to the fustian produced, but can to the two waistcoats—they were in my shop window.
EDWIN SOAMES . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Paradise-street, St. Luke's. The male prisoner pawned these two waistcoats on the 11th of October.

FREDERICK LANGTON (policeman.) On the 9th of Oct. I saw the male prisoner lurking about Mr. Nickenson's shop—I afterwards went to the female prisoner, and took her—I found a piece of fustian at the pawnbroker's—I asked her how she came by it—she said her son gave it her to sell, and not having money she pawned it, and gave him the money.
Robinson's Defence. I found them under the boards of a new house.
WILLIAM WALKER (policeman.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner Robinson's former conviction—(read)—he is the person.

ROBINSON—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

CLEMENTS—
NOT GUILTY .

3100.
JAMES WALLACE was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Oct., 4lbs. weight of tobacco, value 16s., the goods of
John Dale, his master.

JOHN DALE . I live in Surrey-lane, Southwark; the prisoner was my car
man. On the 12th of Oct. he went to London-bridge wharf to load out various goods which came by the steam packets—I did not deliver this cask of tobacco to him, nor see it till it was afterwards at Fenning's-wharf; but here is the delivery-book to prove he had it—I cannot prove he had it—there was a vacant space in the cask at Fenning's-wharf—he had this delivery-book that day—my clerk, who attends the wharf, made the entry.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Is there anybody here from London
bridge wharf who saw it put into his wagon? A. No, nor that it was deli
vered
at Fenning's-wharf, out of any wagon—the Magistrate said there was no occasion—the clerk who made the entry in this book is not here—I cannot swear there is any deficiency, except from the book.
JOHN THOROWGOOD . I am a dealer in marine stores. On the 12th of Oct., about eight o'clock at night, the prisoner came to my shop with some tobaceo—I did not buy it—it was left there.

THOMAS WEST . I saw the prisoner go into the shop with something under his arm—I passed the door, and saw something in the scale, I went and told my brother constable, returned, and found the tobacco under the counter.
MR. DALE re-examined. I only sent him for what there was to load—I cannot myself prove he had the tobacco—this is the same description as that on the cask—the book is not signed by the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

3101.
JOHN HARRIS was indicted
for embezzlement.
SARAH LYON . The prisoner used to bring beer from Mrs. Wood—I paid him 2s. 6d. on her account on the 15th of May.
HARRIET BARTLET . I deal with Mrs. Wood. On the 22nd of May I paid the prisoner about 2s. 6d. on her account—I cannot say how much.
ELIZA BLOWS . I am the wife of George Blowe. On the 22nd of May I paid the prisoner 1s. on Mrs. Wood's account.

ANN WOODS . I keep the Devonshire Arms, Balham-hill. The prisoner was about three months in my service, and left on the 22nd of May without permission—he generally settled every day—he has not accounted for the 2s. 6d. from Lyon, or 1s. from Blowe.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

3102.
JAMES LUCAS and
STEPHEN NOWLAND were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard West, on the 8th of Oct., and stealing therein, 1 counterpane, value 1l.; and 1 pair of trowsers, 1s.; his property.

MARIA WEST . I am the wife of, Richard West, of Grange-road, Ber
mondsey. On Sunday morning, the 8th of Oct., I went to bed at two o'clock—this counterpane was then in a basket in the back kitchen—the window and doors shut and fastened—the kitchen window had not been opened for years—I got up at half-past six next morning, found the window broken open, and hanging on one hinge, and the counterpane and trowsers gone—the trowsers were thrown over the wall—I only lost the counterpane.

WILLIAM WELLERD . I live in Grange-road. About twenty minutes to seven o'clock, on Sunday morning, I was passing the prosecutor's to go to my employ, and saw Nowland on the garden side of the wall, delivering the counterpane over to Lucas—he dropped it into his hands—Lucas tied it up, and put it on his head—I went to look for a constable, and lost sight of them—I knew them before, and swear to them—I returned to the house, and found a constable there—I described them—he went into the street, and took Nowland.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What are you? A. A leather factor—I work for about half an hour on Sundays—I thought this was a robbery, and went for a constable.

WILLIAM FORDHAM (policeman.) I observed the window of West's house about seven o'clock in the morning—it had been forced open by some instru
ment—I apprehended Nowland,
JOHN WRIGHT (policeman.) I took Lucas, with the counterpane on his head, about five minutes to seven o'clock—Nowland was taken first, but they had separated.

LUCAS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

NOWLAND—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

3103.
THOMAS GRANT was indicted
for burglariously breaking into the dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Hackett, about twelve in the night of the 9th of April, at
St. John Southwark, and stealing therein, 24 shirts, value 2l. 8s.; and 10 pairs of trowsers, 7l., her property; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH HACKETT . I am single, and live in Thornton-street, Dockhead, in the parish of St. John, Horsley down. On Saturday night, the 10th of April, I went to bed at ten o'clock, leaving the shop quite safe—I awoke just before twelve, looked out of window, and saw the door, as I thought, safe—I saw two women standing on the side facing my shop—I heard a noise, but saw nothing, and went to bed again—I got up at seven, found the fan
light broken, and missed twenty-four shirts, and seven pairs of trowsers—I know these eleven shirts to be mine, and part of what I missed.

GEORGE GALE . I live in Brewer Vcourt, Horsleydown, and sell ginger-beer. I came out about four o'clock in the morning of the 10th of April, and observed the prisoner and four others come by my stand from towards the prosecutrix's shop—I am certain the prisoner was one—I asked if they wanted any coffee—they went on about twenty yards, stopped, and talked together—they then came towards my stand again, and one of them, who has since been convicted, took a cane off my stand—I told him to put it down—he would not—the prisoner came back and told him to put it down, or they should get blown, or some such word—they then went on to the bottom of the street into New-street—I saw them again at the end of a court facing the prosecutrix's shop—they staid there some time, as if talking to somebody, then went down the court again, and three of them came up the street—the prisoner was one—two females stopped down the street under the lamp—the men stopped by the prosecutrix's shop—two of them went down the court, and came back, then the prisoner went down and came back—the two men crossed the road, and went down the other side of the way, the prisoner kept on this side, and I lost sight of him.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You are not very certain "blown" was the word he used? A. No—they only passed me twice—they came up towards me three or four times—they were together—I saw the females down at the bottom of the street—that might be 200 yards from me—the three men were then toge
ther, close against the house—they were at one time all five together—both the other men were taller than the prisoner, and one was taller than the other—one of them spoke to me as they passed—I cannot say which—I saw the other two very soon after—the first time I saw the prisoner afterwards was before the Magistrate, on the 2nd of Oct.—I cannot say it was not the prisoner that spoke to me—I was at the corner of the street, just against the curb—it is a broad street—the five did not pass abreast, they were close together—two or three walked side by side—the men were before the women—they crossed over—their sides were to me—I saw their backs and front—I have sold coffee in the street about two years, and ginger-beer also—I am not able to do any
thing else.

THOMAS TURVEY (police-constable N 196.) On the 10th of April, about nine o'clock in the morning, I was going on duty, and saw the prisoner, two other men, and two women, all in company together—I knew them all before—the two women had bundles in their aprons—I took the bundles from them—they contained the articles produced.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you first see them? A. Crossing Red
cross-street—I met them—three men walked in front, and the women behind them—the moment I stopped the women, the three men ran away—I went to get assistance, and followed them a considerable distance before I stopped them—I took the women, because they had the bundles—when I met them I

went about twenty yards, met my sergeant, and then went after them—I saw the prisoner in custody on the 30th of June and the 1st of July, and am posi
tive he is the man—I had known him well for a considerable time.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (policeman.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction—(read)—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

3104.
JOHN WHITE BRIDGMAN and
ISAAC BRIDGMAN were indicted for
unlawfully breaking and entering the grave of
Thomas Ghorst Tawney, and taking away the said body.

JAMES DODSLEY TAWNET . I am the only surviving son of the late Thomas Ghorst Tawney, and shall be forty-seven years old in December. My father had a vault in the chapel of St. John's, West-street, Walworth—he died in Nov. 1803—I was not present at the funeral, but I recollect his death, and the funeral going from the house—at that time I had an elder brother living, named Thomas—he died on the 1st of Jan. 1837—I have no reason to believe that the tomb had ever been opened for the purpose of interments, between the death of my father and that of my brother, who was also buried in that vault—my mother died on the 27th Oct. 1837, and was buried in the same vault in Nov.—I attended the obsequies of my brother and mother—a person named Ashley opened and closed the tomb at both those interments—on both those occasions my father's coffin was entire, the lead part was—the wood, the external case, had decayed—it was wood cased with lead—it was safe and entire, as to the leaden coffin, both in Jan. and Nov. 1837—there was no other coffin interred in the vault in the meantime—I believe my father built the vault himself—I am a solicitor, and carry on business in King-street, Cheapside—I live in Regent-square—on Monday, the 11th of Sept. last, I received information, in conse
quence of which I went, accompanied by Ashley, to the house of the elder Mr. Bridgman, on the same afternoon—the door was opened by a servant, and when I inquired for Mr. Bridgman, she asked my name, which I gave—I saw Mrs. Bridgman—the public entrance to the chapel-yard is through the chapel—the coffins are taken that way into the burial-ground—there is no opening to go into the chapel-yard round the chapel—the only entrance is through the body of the chapel—Mr. Bridgman's house adjoins the chapel—Mr. Courtnall's is on one side, and Mr. Genet's on the other—I did not make known my business to Mrs. Bridgman—I sent my name in, and she said Mr. Bridgman would be there shortly—I saw Mr. Bridgman—I told him I came there for the purpose of opening my family vault, as I wished to see what it contained, and I had the bricklayers at the door for the purpose of opening it—he said nothing—I said, "I have the bricklayers here, I will let them in," and I walked into the passage, and opened the street-door, to let them in—it is a very small house—the parlour-door and street-door were close together—Mr. Bridgman said nothing to me—I walked towards the back part of the house, wishing to go through that way, from information I had obtained that there was a passage through the kitchen—Mrs. Bridgman met me at the door of the kitchen, and told me I could not go that way—I cannot say whe
ther Mr. Bridgman was present—she showed me another way, through a little door by the front parlour-window, which led into the chapel, and from the chapel into the chapel-yard—I went through the chapel into the burial-ground, and went to the tomb of my late father, I saw that the large stone at the top had evidenly been removed, and the brick work damaged—the bricklayer's men re
moved the stone quite off the top of the tomb—I then observed that my mo
ther's

coffin was turned on its side, on to my brother's, and my father's coffin was gone—that is the leaden coffin which I had observed safe in Nov. 1837—there were some pieces of wood lying at the bottom of the tomb, and a patch of hair about the size of my hand—that did not call my particular attention at that time—on the side of my mother's coffin, was a large patch of tallow, at if a candle had been stuck there and guttered—I desired to have my mother's coffin put on its bottom, that I might read the coffin plate on the top of it, and my brother's—the men had a great deal of difficulty in removing it, and talked of taking away the brick-work, but after looking between the lid of my mother's coffin they found this bed-winch jammed in between the lid of mother's coffin and the tomb, so as to make it fast—they could not move it—it has been in my possession ever since—after removing that, they put my mother's coffin flat on its bottom, on to my brother's coffin, not in the place where my father's had been—I directly went through the chapel into Mr. Bridgman's house, I should think that was not exceeding ten minutes after I first saw Mr. Bridgman—I saw the servant, but he was denied to me—I then required to see Mrs. Bridgman, and Mr. John Bridgman, but did not see them—in consequence of what the girl told me with reference to Mr. John Bridg
man, I inquired for the hospital to which I supposed he was gone—I have since ascertained that he was at that time studying for the purpose of becom
ing a surgeon—I did not see him, or any of the family before I left the house that afternoon—after this, I consulted Mr. Clarkson on the subject, in consequence of which, on Saturday the 16th, I went to Union Hall, and applied for a warrant with reference to the younger defendant—I tbink no warrant was granted at that time—the elder defendant was summoned—he attended, and engaged to produce his son, who he represented to be away on the 27th—he did not appear on the 27th—on the 19th of Sept., I wrote a let
ter to Mr. Bridgman, and received an answer—in consequence of further in
formation, on the 21st, I applied for a search warrant, and proceeded with it and Pritchard to the chapel-yard in question—I observed a spot which denoted that the earth had been recently removed—by my direction the earth was re
moved from that spot, and within five or six inches of the surface, a wooden coffin cased with lead was discovered—that was fifteen yards from the defen
dant's back premises—there was no lid to it—there appeared to have been one—the nail holes were perceptible at the side where the lid had been made fast—it was filled with loose earth, and some bones—the officers emptied it, and took it out, and it was left for some days in the chapel-yard in the custody of the police, day and night—after some days, the fragments of wood that I had seen in the tomb, on the 11th, were applied to the coffin, and it formed the entire wooden lid—it had been broken to pieces, and a hole knocked in the middle at the widest part, and when the whole was put together it fitted exactly, might have been nailed on through the old nail holes—I think the coffin was found on Wednesday the 21st, and it occurred to me on Saturday the 24th to do this—I made an appointment with the police on the Monday, to have the tomb fresh opened, and was obliged to have the bricklayers again to re
move the stones—every possible search was made to find the lead belonging to the lid, but we could not find it—there was a little fir tree which appeared to have been recently planted a few feet from where the coffin was found—we searched there, and everywhere else where we saw any earth recently removed, but did not find the lead—we found bones, and skulls in different parts—close to the head of my father's coffin, we found three skulls, and in an
other spot quite close to the loose earth we found another skull—the part where the coffin was found, was in a little border to the left of a gravel walk that leads from the back of Mr. Bridgman's premises up to the stable—it was

not a place that appeared at all used for burial—in searching for the leaden lid, there was a tombstone raised on brick-work, which had evidently been pulled out—it was all loose—the bricklayers put their hands in, and pulled out three coffin plates—that was not my father's tomb.
COURT. Q. There was evidence that the ground had been disturbed for other purposes? A. Yes.

GEORGE GARFORD . I am a clerk in Messrs. Richards and Co.'s linen factory, in Bread-street, Cheapside, and am the son of Mrs. Courtnall; at the time in question I resided with her and my step-father, next door to Mr. Bridgman's, in West-street, Walworth. On Wednesday night, the 6th of Sept., I went to bed about eleven o'clock—I slept on the second floor, at the back of the house, which overlooks the chapel-yard in question—I put out my candle and drew up my blind, and on doing so, I fancied I saw some
thing moving in the burial-ground—it immediately attracted my attention—I looked again, and in about five minutes' time I observed three men coming from the direction of the wall that separates the burial-ground from our garden, and go in the direction of Mr. Tawney's tomb—that was in the direction they would have come from Mr. Bridgman's house, without going through the chapel—I did not at that time know whose tomb it was—one of the persons appeared to have nothing on but a shirt, and a cloak over it—one of the others had a cloak, and the other, as far as I could see, was dressed in plain black clothes—I did not see the tomb opened—I observed that it was open—the stone that had been on it was removed to the side—I saw one of the men, I believe the undressed one with the cloak on, descend into the tomb, and saw something handed from the tomb—I also saw it carried away by two of them, one carrying it at each end—they appeared to carry it with great difficulty—I saw some ropes—I could not distinguish whether or not it was lifted up by those ropes—there was perhaps not sufficient light for me to dis
cern whether what was taken out was a coffin, but I made the remark at the time that it was a coffin—it made that impression on me at the time—the third man then got out of the tomb—the other two carried the coffin in the direction of the wall from where I first saw them come—that is in a direct line with Mr. Bridgman's passage—after they got to a certain extent under the wall I could not see them, from the position of my window—it would lead them towards the house—(before I saw the coffin taken from the tomb, I had given an alarm to my father and mother)—the men afterwards returned from the wall where they appeared to have deposited what they took away, and all three returned to the tomb again—I then saw a lantern—it appeared to be brought from Mr. Bridgman's stable, which is in the burial-ground—one of them descended into the tomb with the lantern, the other two remained about the tomb—after the space of about ten minutes, I observed the party come out of the tomb again—I saw nothing more of the light after it was taken into the tomb—I saw a man bring a lever, or long wooden pole, from the direction of the stable, and replace the stone.

Q. Had you, in the course of this time, an opportunity of observing any one of the three persons, so as to enable you to speak to him? A. Only from his general appearance and action—I could not see his face, on account of the distance—I have known young Bridgman for a long time—I believe him to have been one of the three, the one that was undressed and had the cloak on—I could scarcely see whether he had shoes and stockings on—the wind blew about his cloak, when he had the lantern, which gave me an op
portunity of seeing his person and appearance, and that assisted me in coming to the belief that it was young Bridgman—I had not seen him wear a cloak at any time that I remember.

COURT. Q. Then what do you mean by his appearance, if you could not see his face? A. From his height, manner, and actions; seeing him running backwards and forwards from the stable to the tomb—I had observed his style and gait before—I cannot say that there was anything peculiar about it—I was familiar with his mode of moving quickly.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. At that time had you any doubt that he was one of the three? A. No; on seeing this, I immediately went, hurried on what clothes I could, and went down stairs with the intention of going into the street, see whether any of the men went out that way—when I got into the passage, I heard something very heavy put down in Bridgman's passage—I made the remark at the time, that it was very heavy—I heard it distinctly, and called my father's attention to the fact—I proceeded to the outer door, opened it, and heard Mr. Bridgman's door open about the same time—I then observed a man come from the door of Mr. Bridgman's house—there is a wooden screen between the two houses, to prevent any one seeing the entrance in and out of the other—a man came from Mr. Bridgman's house, and went as far as the gate—the screen near the gate is not so high as it is near the door, and I saw him when he got near the gate—he looked over the screen, saw me, returned into the house again, and shut the door—I went into our house again, left the door ajar, and listened for a few minutes—in about five minutes Mr. Bridg
man's door was opened again—I went to the door, and saw the man return again—that was certainly not young Bridg man—I heard the man say to the party who let him out, "Good night, ma'am "—(I had observed lights through the fan-light over the door, between the first and second times of the man's coming out)—he then went away, and walked towards Kennington—after he had walked about fifteen yards, he turned his head and saw me, as I had gone into the street, and then he ran as fast as he could—I ran after him for some time, but lost sight of him—he was the man that was dressed in plain black clothes—Mr. Bridgman kept a horse and chaise—whilst the men were at the tomb, I saw the horse come from the stable—I also saw a dog in the chapel-yard, while this was going on—I had seen it about the place before, it was quite quiet, it did not appear to treat the parties as strangers—I was not aware whose dog it was—I had to go to business early next morning—I re
turned about half-past seven in the evening, which was half an hour earlier than usual, for the purpose of following out this proceeding—I went to the same window from time to time, for two or three hours, to see if I could observe anybody; and a little before ten I saw two men at Mr. Tawney's tomb—they had a lever—(it appeared to me that the stone top of the tomb had been imperfectly put on the night before)—they used the lever in the same way as on the previous evening, to adjust the tomb-stone—they then came in the direction of Mr. Bridgman's house—young Bridgman was one of those men—I observed, when I saw him at the tomb, that he had a grey coloured coat on, cut in the shape of a shooting-jacket; and when they had completed what they were about at the tomb, and came in the direction of Mr. Bridgman's house, I went to the front of the house, looked through the win
dow, and observed this party, dressed in the same way, come from Mr. Bridg
man's house—I immediately ran down stairs, and followed him into the Wal
worth-road, without losing sight of him—I then passed him twice, and saw his face distinctly—I also heard him talking to somebody, and am sure it was young Bridgman—I then consulted my relatives, and thought it my duty to examine the tomb, to see to whom it belonged; and, on ascertaining, I ex
amined the directory, to trace the relatives, which led me to Mr. Tawney's office, to whom I disclosed all I had seen.
JAMES COURTNALL . I married the mother of the last witness, and live next
door to the minister of West-street chapel, Walworth—my attention was called by my step-son to what took place on the night of the 6th—I cannot identify any of the parties.

ELIZABETH COURTNALL . I am the wife of last witness. On Wednesday night, the 6th of Sept., my attention was called to what took place in the chapel-yard next to our house—I saw three men engaged at the tomb—one of them was undressed, and had a cloak on—the other two, I think, were in black—two had cloaks on—I saw the dog in the ground, it was quiet—I saw the horse come out of the stable—on Monday, the 18th of Sept., from ten till one o'clock in the day, I was at our back window, and saw the elder defeudant at the wall of his ground, which separates our two houses—it was formerly a garden, but is now part of the chapel-yard—he seemed to be gardening, mak
ing a border—I am not sure whether I saw a spade—he bad no coat on—I cannot say for certain that he was digging, as my husband was gardening at the time, and it might have been his spade that I heard.

HANNAH COURTNALL . I am the daughter of Mr. Courtnall. About a fortnight before the 6th of Sept. last, I was walking in the garden, and heard Mr. Bridgman, senior, saying that some men had been seen in the burial-ground the night before—I do not know who he said it to—on the night of the 6th my attention was called to what was going on—I slept in the same room with Priscilla Terry, the servant—on the night alter I saw a man come out of Mr. Bridgman's house, and saw my brother follow him—shortly after, I was looking out of our second-floor window, which is even with Mr. Bridgman's second floor, and saw a female in her night-dress, looking out of the window—I am not able to say it was Mrs. Bridgman, but I think it was—at the same time I thought I saw a man with a hat on, looking out of the other window—I do not speak with any positiveness about that—that is their bedroom—I heard somebody talking in Mr. Bridgman's first floor, and heard some one say, "As long as my name is Bridgman"—it was a roan's voice—I thought I heard the voices of two men—I know the elder Mr. Bridgman's voice, and I thought it was his voice—I do not attend his chapel—on the following morning, about nine o'clock, or between nine and ten, I saw Mr. Bridgman's horse and chaise at the door; and between ten and twelve that same morning I saw Mr. Bridgman coming out of the chapel in West-street—he passed me—I saw his face distinctly—I was at home about ten o'clock in the evening, while my brother was watching, I saw the two men at the tomb, but could not distinguish young Bridgman—I saw my brother go out after one of them.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. The horse and chaise, I suppose, was one Mr. Bridgman, the elder, was in the habit of riding in? A. Yes—I was looking out of our first-floor front window when I saw the chaise—I saw it come, I did not see anybody in it—I beard it come to the door, and some one had just jumped out of it when I saw it—I heard them jump out—I had to go out twice that morning, and I do not remember whether it was the first or second time that I saw Mr. Bridgman—I passed him in the open street—I did not speak to him, nor he to me—I had to go about half a mile, and then I returned home.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know whether Mr. Bridgman was in the habit of having his horse and chaise as early as that hour in the morning at his door? A. Yes.

PRISCILLA TERRY . I was in Mr. Courtnall's service. On Wednesday evening, 6th Sept., a little before seven o'clock, I was looking out of the window up stairs, and saw the elder Mr. Bridgman in his garden, coming in a direction from the stable to the back part of his house—a little time after, I was down

stairs, and heard a digging in Mr. Bridgman's garden—I slept in the same room with Miss Courtnall, and my attention was called to what was going on in the chapel-yard that night—I saw Mr. Garford follow one of the men next evening—after that I heard some two or three men's voices in Mr. Bridgman's house—one of the men said, "I will tell you what it is, John," and, "As sure as my name is Bridgman"—those two observations I heard at intervals, in the course of some conversation—I did not know the first voice—I thought the second voice was young Bridgman's—I have no belief as to the other voice—it was not familiar to me—I continued listening and looking out of window after that, and saw a woman look out of Mr. Bridgman's second-floor window—I thought it was Mrs. Bridgman—I also thought that I saw a man's hat at the other window of that bedroom—about eight o'clock next morning I heard young Bridgman's voice in the garden, calling "Father"—I heard no answer—he went down the garden, towards the stable, as if he was going to his father, as he did not hear him—I had not seen or heard the elder Mr. Bridgman that morning—I do not know exactly when I next saw him—I think I saw him next day in his garden, but I am not certain.

Cross-examined. Q. This way from the stable, that you speak of, comes along close by the wall, does it not? A. Yes—Mr. Bridgman is very often in his garden—it was from half-past six to seven o'clock on Wed
nesday, that I saw him—it was not dusk—I merely went into the room, looked out of the window, and came away directly.

EDWARD GENET . I am a clerk in the Custom-house, and live on one side of the chapel, and Mr. Bridgman on the other. I have a lodger who keeps a little dog—it is a very sharp little dog, which barks at strangers and persons coming in and out—I used sometimes to be bothered with its barking of a night, and have gone out to see what was going on—about a month before this transaction, I heard from the servant at No. 17, that some persons had been seen in the burial ground the night before—I mentioned the circumstance to Mr. Bridgman next evening, and his son was in the yard at the time—Mr. Bridg
man made use of a scriptural quotation, and said it did not matter so much if the spirit was at rest, about the bones being disturbed; but if I thought there was any likelihood of anybody coming into the chapel-yard, he would have a watch set—I said I thought it might be a fancy of the lady next door—he said perhaps it was his servant-girl, that she walked in her sleep, and per
haps she walked into the chapel-yard—he said he had occasion, some years since, to attend at Union-hall about a transaction of that kind, which took place in his yard—I saw a fir-tree planted about the 11th or 12th, which was not there before, to my knowledge.

SARAH GENET . A lodger of ours had a dog, which used to disturb us by constantly barking—I heard from a lady at No. 17, that some persons had been seen in the burial-ground, and remember my husband stating that to Mr. Bridgman, who replied, that he did not think any one came after the bodies in the ground—he made some scriptural allusion, and said if the spirits were at rest, it did not so much signify about the bodies—I do not recollect the exact words, but he said if my husband thought so, he would have a watch in the yard—my husband said, no, he did not think it was required—Mr. Bridg
man said he did not know that any persons had come there for a very long time, once there was a case of some persons being taken up, and he had to appear against them—about a fortnight or three weeks before this tomb was disturbed, young Bridgman borrowed the lodger's dog—he said his father's horse shyed at dogs, and he wanted to make it used to dogs—I think he had a little fancy dog of his own at that time—he returned the lodger's dog in about a week.

Q. Did the dog bark then in the same way it wed to do, or had it become much more quiet? A. If strangers came into the ground it barked, it would not bark at young Bridgman—the dog constantly ran in and out the burial-ground, and seemed acquainted with the whole of the family—I do not know whether it barked at them after this, it might occasionally—it did not some
times—when young Bridgman returned it, the lodger offered to give it to him—he said he thought the horse was broken to the dog, and he had no fur
ther use for it, that they were going to dispose of the horse, to they would not wish it any further—on Thursday, the 21st of Sept., I was in my garden and saw Mr. Bridgman digging in his garden—I saw the spot where the coffin was afterwards found—it was not at that spot I saw him digging—it was on the same side, but nearer the stable—he was spreading the earth about with his spade—there was nothing hanging there at the time—I saw a coun
terpane or sheet hanging there the day before, but he was not there then—the coffin was found, I should say, three or four yards from where I saw him digging—it was in the same direction.

Cross-examined. Q. Was this on the 18th of Sept, which has been spoken of? A. I do not know the day of the month—it was on a Tuesday, I think, about eleven in the day—I never saw young Bridgman's dog—I heard him say he had one, but it would not bark, and therefore he wished to borrow one to accustom the horse to it—the fence dividing our premises from Mr. Bridgman's, has gaps in it—the palings have been broken down in places, which the dog could get through—he had been in the habit of going in and out of Mr. Bridgman's premises as he liked, ever since we have been in the house—it had the same opportunity of being familiar with Mr. Bridgman's family before it was borrowed as after.

MOSES REDDING . I am a baker, and live at No. 8, Staverton-row, Wal
worth-road. On the 6th of Sept. I remember seeing the elder Mr. Bridgman at Ramsgate, at the door of Cavendish chapel, about a quarter to nine o'clock, within a few minutes; I cannot say to a minute or two—I was with him for a quarter of an hour at least, in conversation.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How came you at Ramsgate on the 6th of Sept.? A. I went down there on pleasure—I went on the 6th—there is no one here that went with me—I went by steam, arrived at Margate about a quarter to five o'clock, and went from there to Ramsgate by a buss—I believe the vessel I went by was the Herne, but I am not certain—I got to Ramsgate at half-past six—I did not go down in the same boat with Mr. Bridgman—I had no lodging there when I saw Mr. Bridgman at a quarter to nine, for I had just arrived there—I slept there afterwards—before I saw Mr. Bridgman I had been along with a part of my brother's family that was down at Margate, in George-place—I do not know that any of them are here—I went by myself—I am married—Cavendish-chapel is in Devonshire-street, near George-street or George-place—I never was there but once before, and am not certain of the name of the place or street—I know it was Cavendish-chapel, because my sister-in-law told me so—I believe it is a dissenting chapel, but do not know—I am a dissenter—I have not attended Mr. Bridgman's chapel for many years—my sister's family go to Cavendish-chapel occasionally—they had been staying down there five or six weeks—it was outside the chapel that I saw Mr. Bridgman, after service was over—I cannot say how long be
fore I had seen him; it might be some days or weeks—I have known him for years—I am not in the habit of seeing him frequently—I do not visit at his house—I have not been there above once these four or five years—I was

speaking to him on this occasion about the sermon we had heard, and about his stopping down at Ramsgate—Mortlock Daniels preached that night—I have lived eighteen years in Staverton-place, and am a miller as well as a baker—I left my family in town while I went to Ramsgate, at least I left my home; but I left my wife where she has been for some time, she is out of her mind—I have one child—he is grown up.

Q. You understood from Mr. Bridgman's conversation that he had been to the chapel and heard the sermon? A. No; we met at the door—I cannot tell what it was we said about the sermon, but I know we were speaking about Mr. Daniels taking up the subject—I can tell you the text, or nearly so; it was the promise of Jacob about going down to Egypt, "I will go with thee into Egypt, and be sure to bring you back," or something of that sort, to the best of my recollection, I forget exactly, I am not certain of the chap
ter and verse; I think it was in Genesis, but I will not say positively—we conversed together for a quarter of an hour—nobody else was with us—we walked down the town towards where he was lodging, which, I think, was on some terrace, but I really do not know, I did not ask him—I did not see him on the following day—I went to Margate to meet ray friend, who I was to have met there on the Tuesday—I staid with my brother's family that night, and went away next morning—I came out of chapel with my brother's wife—I do not recollect that any one else of my brother's family was there—my brother's wife was at the chapel when I got down there, and I followed her—I did not take her home;
