I left her, and joined Mr. Bridgman—I do not know whether she saw me join Mr. Bridgratn or not, because I came out behind her—I was not with her in the chapel—I went into another pew where they put me—I did not know where to find her—I was never there before—I went to the chapel to hear a sermon—I knew my brother's wife was at the chapel, but not where to find her—the chapel was only three or four doors from where I was lodging—my attention was not called to this case for a week after I came back—I came back on the Monday after the 6th—I have not been asked about being in Ramsgate on the 6th of Sept. till I came here—I might have made a statement in consequence of inquiries about the 6th of Sept., but I do not know when, and I do not know whether I have been asked about it by anybody—I offered to come forward for Mr. Bridgman when I heard of it—I went and told Mr. Bridgman that I was down there on that very same day—that might have been a fortnight or three weeks ago, since there has been an inquiry at Union-hall—I went and asked Mr. Bridgman whether he could recollect that he was down there with me, and if he could recollect the day of the month—he said he could not exactly go into the particulars—I told him it was the 6th, and I understood, from inquiries at Union-hall, that it was the 6th it was com
mitted, and I said, "I was with you on the 6th till nearly nine o'clock, and I will come forward and state it anywhere"—I did not attend at Union-hall at first—the last time I was there—I have never been examined by anybody as to the evidence I was to give, and I never would be—I went to Union-hall to hear the case, and if Mr. Bridgman, as I expected he would do, wanted evi
dence to prove he was away from home, I intended giving it—I never spoke to any solicitor, or anybody else—I never was at Ramsgate but once before, and I think that is about ten years ago—I went this time to see my brother's family—my brother is a coach-builder, in Morton-street, Cavendish-square—before I was a miller I was a farmer, which I left twenty years ago—I am a housekeeper—I have known Mr. Bridgman from ten to fourteen years.

COURT. Q. What time did you leave London to go out of town on that day? A. I think eleven o'clock—I went from London-bridge—I got to Margate somewhere about five—I staid there about ten minutes or a quarter

of an hour, I cannot say to a few miutes, it was a very short time—I then went on to Ramsgate, to my brother's family—I got there, I think, about seven—I found my brother's wife and one daughter there—my brother was in London—I staid in the house but a very short period before I went to chapel, only a few minutes—I did not go to chapel with my brother's wife, I went after them—my brother's wife was not in the house when I got there—when I said just now that she was there, I meant that she was at Ramsgate—she had gone to chapel—directly I got into the chapel the pew-opener opened a pew and put me in—after leaving Mr. Bridgman, I returned to my brother's, and slept there—it took me about five minutes to get there after leaving Mr. Bridgman—I did not know my way—I in
quired—I did not see anything of my brother's wife at the chapel—I was told they were there—I went off from the door with Mr. Bridgman—I dined as I went down that day—I had what I may call tea at a house in Margate, at least a cup of coffee, and a piece of bread and butter, just before I started—I supped at my brother's—I think we had a part of a loin of mutton—my brother's wife, daughter, and I sat down to supper—there was only one daughter then—part of the family had come home the week previous—I left about nine o'clock next morning for Margate—I had no friends at Margate, but I was to meet persons named Brown and Gilham there, whom I had agreed to go down with, but circumstances prevented their going on Tuesday, and I went down before them—I found them on the Thursday—I staid there till the next day, in Brown's company, and we came up together on Monday—I know it was on the 6th that I saw Mr. Bridgman, because I was to have gone down on the Tuesday, but the party I was goiog with could not go that day—I said I would go on the following day, if they would send a note to my house, and they did so—Mr. Brown was at my house on the Monday evening—I did not see Mr. Bridgman coming out of the chapel—I talked to him as if he had been one of the hearers, and I was asking the view he took of the sermon—he told me he had been in the chapel, and I am quite sure he had, from the conversation I had with him—I think service began about seven o'clock—it had begun when I arrived—it lasted till a quarter to nine, as near as I can recollect, I cannot tell to a few minutes, I had no watch, but I got back about nine, or a few minutes past—my sister said, "How came you out so late, do you know what time it is?"—I said, "Yes, somewhere about nine," and she said, "It is five minutes past nine."
MR. BODKIN. Q. Did she see Mr. Bridgman? A. No, neither did she know him.

THOMAS CHAPMAN . I reside in Burton-crescent—I am in no business or profession—I keep the house, and have lived there about eleven years. I was at Ramsgate in the early part of Sept. last—I am acquainted with Mr. Bridgman—I saw him at Ramsgate on the 5th, 6th, and 7th of Sept.—I met him on the pier, and had conversation with him—he dined with a friend of mine on the 6th, and I was with him again on the 7th—it was Wednesday the 6th, Thursday the 7th, and Friday the 8th—it was my error saying the 5th, 6th, and 7th—it was the 6th, 7th, and 8th—Wednesday was the first day I saw him—he dined with my friend on the Thursday, and I saw him again on the Friday, and took leave of him—(looking at a letter)—this is a letter which I wrote on the subject on the 25th of Oct.—I have known Mr. Bridgman about twelve years as a most respectable character—I have not been on per
fect intimacy with him, but, as a minister of the truth, I always esteemed him, and have always heard of his most excellent character.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you never in any business? A. Yes, the pro
prietor of the "Globe" newspaper, and am so still—it was at Mr. Thompson's house that Mr. Bridgman dined on the Thursday—I have nothing particular

which enables me to fix on the 6th as the day I first saw Mr. Bridgman, but I had a friend coming down, and I was waiting for him at the packet—I did not see Mr. Bridgman arrive—I met him on the pier about three or four o'clock in the afternoon—I did not go with him from the pier—we walked a little on the pier, and I had some conversation of a particular nature with him—I am quite sure I cannot be mistaken in the day—I believe I went to Rams
gate about the 10th of Aug.—I made an entry in my pocket-book, of expect
ing my friend down on the 6th of Sept., as I expected him to dinner—I know it was on the 6th I met Mr. Bridgman on the pier, because I was waiting for my friend, whom I expected that day.

COURT. Q. He did not come? A. No—I was not certain of his coming on that day, but I thought he might—when I saw Mr. Bridgman on the Fri
day, he was going off by the packet, as I understood, for Dover—I saw him on the pier, and conversed with him—I walked daily on the pier, expecting my friend—I do not know that I had been on the pier on the 5th—I did not always go there—my friend never came—I generally walked on the pier every day for recreation—I made no memorandum of seeing Mr. Bridgman, but the circumstance of expecting my friend riveted it more on my mind, because I entered that in my book—my knowledge of Mr. Bridgman is very casual—I have applied to him more than once, I believe, to preach for a charity, or some
thing of that kind—I never visited at his house, only to call on him to beg him to preach—I cannot say whether he had servants to open the door—I think a servant opened the door—on one occasion I invited him to dine with me, when he was to preach—that is the only occasion I have been in private with him—I have often heard him preach—I cannot say whether he keeps servants or not.

EDWIN EVANS LEECH . I live at No. 7, Upper Sussex-place, Old Kent-road, and am in the Stamp and Tax Office. In the early part of Sept. I was at Ramsgate, and, on Thursday, the 7th of Sept., saw Mr. Bridgman there about nine o'clock in the evening—I also saw him on the following day.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where did you see him on the 7th? A. On the pier—I had been a fortnight at Ramsgate for relaxation—I do not know Mr. Chapman or Mr. Redding—I have known Mr. Bridgman about ten years or more—I became acquainted with him through friends and relatives of mine, my father for instance—he is not in any business—he is a housekeeper, and so am I—I know it was Thursday, the 7th, that I saw him, because I invited him to dine with me, and he regretted that a previous invitation would not allow him to do so—I then wished him to name the subsequent day, Friday—he said he could not, for he was going to start in the boat that afternoon for Dover—I was lodging at Ramsgate with my family—I have occasionally at
tended Mr. Bridgman's chapel at Walworth, but not regularly—I am not re
lated to him—I do not recollect whether I was on the pier on the Wednesday afternoon when the Ramsgate packet arrived—I was on the Thursday—I was at Cavendish Chapel on the Wednesday night—I did not see Mr. Bridgman there—I went there to hear a popular preacher, a Mr. Daniels—I do not re
collect the text—it is a Dissenting chapel—I do not know how often they have service in the week—I do not know what time service begins in the week—I went about a quarter past seven o'clock—I do not know what time I came out—it might be a little after eight—I did not observe—I was there somewhere about an hour, I think—I do not think it could have been two hours—I then went home to where I was staying, at Belle Vue, on the eastern cliff—I took tea at home that night about ten—I got home about a quarter to ten—I went circuitously home from the chapel, by the sea side, round the sands—it took me about an hour to get home—to the best of my recollection there was a clock in the chapel—service was over when I left—I do not know whether it

was as late as a quarter to nine when I left the chapel—I said eight because I went about a quarter past seven, and was there, I thought, about an hour, or it might be a little more, I really cannot say—I cannot tell whether it was a long sermon—I think I had been there about twice during my stay at Rams
gate—I took a note of seeing Mr. Bridgman on the 7th.

Q. How soon were you applied to about this after you came to town? A. I was applied to by a letter, which appeared to have miscarried, about a week ago—I do not know the contents of it—I came forward spontaneously, on seeing the accounts in the papers—I was not before the Magistrate.

COURT. Q. Were you on the pier on Thursday, when the packet arrived? A. Yes—there were two arrived, one about four o'clock, and the other about five—I do not know whether any packets arrived before—I do not know at what time all the packets arrive.

CHARLES TOWNLEY . I reside in West-street, Camberwell—I hold, an ap
pointment in the Trinity-house, and have done so thirty-seven years—I have known Mr. Bridgman twelve or thirteen years, ever since he has been there—I was at Ramsgate previous to Sept., and remained there up to the 14th or 15th of Sept.—I met Mr. Bridgman there on Wednesday morning, the 6th of Sept., about a quarter or twenty minutes past nine, in Ramsgate harbour—I spoke to him, and was in company with him on and off for an hour and a half, witnessing the landing of some troops and horses from a transport—I saw him again, about a quarter past five that afternoon, coming from Camden
square, between there and High-street, on my way to Broad-street—I merely passed the compliments of the day to him then, as a lady was with him—I saw him again either on Thursday or Friday morning, but I cannot say which, at Ramsgate.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What enables you to fix on Wednesday the 6th of Sept.? A. I am satisfied it was that day, because that very morning the China transport came into the harbour with troops, and a number of persons went down to see them disembark—I went to see it, and met Mr. Bridgman there—it is stated in Lloyd's list, that the China arrived on the 6th, and a part of my family went to Dover that day, and in their absence I went over to Broadstairs—on my way there, met Mr. Bridgman coming from Camden
square—I have Lloyd's list in my hand, which states that the China arrived at Ramsgate on the 6th—I am sure the vessel I saw was the China—I saw her name—I have very seldom been to Mr. Bridgman's chapel—I have lived in West-street twenty-six or twenty-seven years—I was at Ramsgate three weeks—(referring to a memorandum)—I went on the 26th of August—I have no memorandum of meeting Mr. Bridgman on the 6th of Sept.

MR. BODKIN. Q. What made you go to Broadstairs? A. I had engaged with a part of my family that went to Dover on the Wednesday, that we would go to Broadstairs in the afternoon, and meet them on their return—I am quite satisfied that it was on that very same day I saw Mr. Bridgman—the China had arrived from Quebec.

COURT. Q. Did you meet Mr. Bridgman on the pier? A. Yes; I did not see him land—he was walking at the end of the pier to view the troops dis
embarking—the usual hour of the packets arriving from London, was three or four, and sometimes five, it depended on the wind and tide—two came every day.

CHARLES TOWNLEY JUN . I am a commercial clerk, and live in Camber
well-grove. I was at Ramsgate early in Sept., and saw Mr. Bridgman there on Wednesday the 6th, and Thursday the 7th—I had no conversation with him.

MR. CLARKON. Q. Were you acquainted with him at all? A. I have known him for the last ten years, I think ever since he has been at West-street chapel, and should know him when I met with him—I went to Dover on the 6th of Sept. about half-past nine in the morning, and saw him on Ramsgate pier about that time—I returned the same afternoon—I do not know when Mr. Bridgman was staying—I was not applied to to become a witness, I came forward voluntarily about a fortnight ago.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Was that from observing in the newspapers a report of what was taking place before the Magistrate? A. Yes—I was not applied to by Mr. Bridgman—I more particularly remember seeing him on Thursday morning, about twelve o'clock, on the sands—I was going towards Broad
stairs—I have not the slightest doubt about it—I was only there one week—I went down on Saturday, the 2nd of Sept., and returned on the 9th—I only went to Dover that one Wednesday, and it was as I was starting that I saw him on the pier, and next morning my daughter and younger sister were riding on donkeys on the sands, towards Broadstairs, and they almost ran over Mr. Bridgman.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is your daughter here? A. No—she is only seven years of age.

JOHN MASON THOMPSON . I live at No. 9, Chancery-lane. I was at Rams
gate in the early part of Sept., and saw Mr. Bridgman, whom I knew, there on Thursday the 7th, as near as I can recollect, between twelve and one o'clock—a particular circumstance enables me to speak accurately to the day—not knowing how long he might continue at Ramsgate, I asked him to fix a time to dine with me—he named the next day, but as I was engaged on the next day to dine with some friends, I told him I was sorry I could not receive him then, but should be glad if he would dine with me that day, and after some little hesitation, he said, "Well, I did not promise to return to my friends, and therefore I will do so," and accordingly he dined with me on Thursday the 7th—but for that circumstance I certainly should not have recollected the day.

COURT. Q. Why, did he not tell you he was going to Dover on Friday? A. I think he said he was going to Dover in the afternoon of the next day, Friday—I am not exactly certain with respect to the conver
sation about Dover—I knew he was going to Dover, but whether it was on the Friday or Saturday, I cannot say.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Are you able to state, on your oath, that he dined with you on Thursday the 7th of Sept.? A. Certainly, I have not the slightest doubt about it—being an invalid, I dined at two o'clock, and that I told him—it was rather later that day, in consequence of there being some little addition made—I am sure I gave him the invitation the morning I met him—I have had a casual acquaintance with him for, perhaps, two or three years, but I never spoke to him above three or four times—he once dined with me at my own house, in consequence of his preaching where I attend—knowing he was to preach in the evening, I asked him to dine with me—I never was in his chapel.

JOSEPH BARBER WILKS . I am cashier to the East India Company, and live at No. 1, Pleasant-place, Camberwell. In the early part of Sept., I was stopping with my family at Ramsgate—I saw Mr. Bridgman there on the 5th of Sept.—I went on the pier with my family, and met Mr. Bridgman unexpectedly, just arrived by the boat—I it was about five, but I cannot state—I did not see him land, but met him on the pier among the people, who then landed from the boat, which came from London—I went

up and shook hands with him, having known him some years, and having a very great respect for him, I said, "Mr. Bridgman, I see you are alone, come home with me," and he accompanied me home with my family—I was living at No. 10, Camden-place—he took tea with us on the 5th, on his ar
rival, and took supper the same evening—I invited him to make my house his home, consequently he breakfasted on the following morning (Wednes
day) dined, took tea, and supped on Wednesday, leaving my house from half past ten till eleven—he breakfasted on Thursday—he did not dine, but took tea, and supped on Thursday, breakfasted and dined on Friday, and on Friday afternoon I and my family accompanied him to the pier, and saw him on board the Dover packet about six o'clock.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What time did you dine on Wednesday? A. We generally dined about two o'clock—we took tea about six—I think he did not stay at home the rest of the evening—he merely took his meals with me—he told me at supper that he had been to chapel—he went out after tea, and re
turned in the evening, I cannot say at what time, perhaps about nine—he told me the text, and the particulars.

COURT. Q. Do you remember the text? A. Yes, it was "Fear not to go down into Egypt, I will go with thee"—or something of that sort, relat
ing to Joseph and his brethren, I think, but I am not quite clear at this moment—he told me the text at the time, and it was rather a remarkable one.
MR. BODKIN. Q. How long have you known him? A. Ten or twelve years, and always considered him a most excellent man.

COURT. Q. Did you ever visit at his house? A. Yes—I have called, and have seen one female servant there—the younger prisoner is his only grown up son—there are three children altogether—-the others are quite children, not old enough to be witnesses—I know the days on which I saw Mr. Bridgman to be the 5th, 6th, and 7th, because I went down on the 23rd of Aug., and had been there a fortnight all but a day—my eldest son was to have come down to spend the last week—I intended remaining four weeks, but the weather being exceedingly fine I wrote to him at the end of the second week to come down a week earlier, and he came down on the 5th, the day Mr. Bridgman did—he is not here—I have a letter here which he wrote on the Monday, saying that he should come down the following day if fine—here is the post-mark of 4th Sept. on it—on the front is the Walworth post-mark, and on the other part is the Ramsgate post-mark of the 5th Sept.—he says on the outside, "I intend coming down to-morrow"—he dined and drank tea with Mr. Bridgman as well as myself.

EDWARD MASON THOMPSON . I am the son of Mr. Thompson, who has been examined—I was with him at Ramsgate in Sept.—I know Mr. Bridg
man, and saw him at Ramsgate on Thursday the 7th of Sept., between one and two o'clock, on the pier with my father.

COURT to GEORGE GARFORD. Q. You state that this occurred on Wed
nesday the 6th, what fixes the day in your mind? A. I can scarcely say what can bring it to my remembrance now—I know I was with Mr. Tawney on the following Monday.

JOHN COLSON . I am an officer of Guy's Hospital. The younger defen
dant has been a student of surgery there for some time, and had the charac
ter of an assiduous, zealous student.

J. W. BRIDGMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Twelve Months.

ISAAC BRIDGMAN—
NOT GUILTY .

3105.
RICHARD NORBURY was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Sept., 2 metal cocks, value 6d.; 1 flannel, 1d.; and 1 bell-crank, 1d.; the goods of
George Giles Weston Thatcher; and that he had been before con
victed of felony.

JAMES FAULKNER . I am a whitesmith, in the employ of George Giles Weston Thatcher, an ironmonger and brazier, at Clapham. On the morning of the 20th of Sept., about half-past eleven o'clock, the prisoner came to the workshop—he did not ask for anything—I saw him take the tap off the board, and put it into his pocket—I did not see him pick the brass crank up—he sat there a little while—I went in to see if my master was in the front shop, and while I was gone he walked out—this is my master's property.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take it off the bench? A. Yes—I can swear to this tap—I took it out of the boiler myself, and put a new one on—I saw you take it off the board on the window ledge, and put it into your pocket—you did not take it from one pocket and put it into another.

ROBERT MOORE (police-constable V 12.) In consequence of information, I took the prisoner into custody, searched him, and found on him these taps, this bell-crank, and several small pieces of iron, which are here.

GEORGE GILES WESTON THATCHER . I am an ironmonger, at Clapham. I have seen this tap about the premises, on the bench—I cannot swear to it—there is always a good deal of metal lying about—the prisoner never worked for me—I have known him at work at different shops in Clapham for these two years.
Prisoner's Defence. It is my own property.

SAMUEL EASOM (policeman.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's for
mer conviction, from the clerk of the peace for Surrey—(read)—I was pre
sent at the trial—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3106.
WILLIAM ROBINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 1 cask, value 3s.; and 445 lbs. weight of white lead, 5l.; the goods of
John Spencer Chadwell; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN SPENCER CHADWELL . I am an oil and colourman, and live in Great Suffolk-street, Southwark. I have seen a cask of white lead in the prisoner's possession, which is my property—I know it by the weight and tare marks on the cask—I had such in my shop on the 23rd of Oct., at six o'clock in the afternoon, and missed it about half-past six or seven next morning—I noticed some marks, which appeared as if some cask had been rolled away—I traced it up the court, at the back of my premises, then went into my shop, and sent for a policeman—I showed him the marks, and fancied he would find my lead by them.
Prisoner. Q. Where did the cask lay? A. At the side of my door, in the road—I have had occasion to complain of boys rolling my casks in the street.

GEORGE WILD (police-constable M 94.) In consequence of information, I went to the court on the following morning, the 24th—I traced the cask di
rectly to the prisoner's door—there are three houses in the court—I knocked, and he looked out of the window—he was then in bed—I knew he lived in that house, but did not know who he was—I asked him to come down and let me in—he did so—he opened the door, and said, "I suppose you are comefor the tub I fell over last night, about half-past eleven or twelve o'clock"—I

said, "I have not said anything at all about any cask"—he took me directlyto the stairs, and in a cupboard was the white lead in the cask—I sent for as
sistance—the prosecutor and his apprentice came, and we got it out—I took it, and took the prisoner into custody.

JANE CHADWELL . I am the prosecutor's wife. On the night in question I saw the prisoner from ten till eleven o'clock—I mentioned the loss of the cask to him—he condoled with my loss, and said no doubt it was sold before it was stolen.

Prisoner's Defence. I fell over the cask in the court, got a light, saw no direction who it belonged to, and took it into my house. When the police
man came, I said, "I suppose you have come for the cask I stumbled over last night, coming home."

JOHN CLEMENTS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former con
viction, from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person tried and convicted.

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

3107.
JAMES HAINES and
EDWARD BYFIELD was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August, 1 rule, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
William Cooper, their master.
MESSRS. PAYNE and CARTEEN conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM COOPER . I am a builder, and live at pulse-bill—the prisoners were in my service, about February last, as plasterers—I believe they were working in Clapham New-park—I had a rule there—I was there almost every day—I saw that rule there afterwards, and it had been altered—it had been made narrower at each end, which was for some purposes more convenient than if it was a regular size all the way through, as I had had it made—this is it—(look
ing at it)—it had been as wide at the ends as it is in the middle—I had it made about twelve months ago—I observed "E B "was cut on it, which had not been on it before—I saw Byfield when be came to the building—I asked how he dared to take and put his name on my rule—he said it was not my rule, that a person named Wren made it for him, for doing a job just above—I said, every man on the building knew it was my rule, by a singular place on it, that Wren never made it, and every person in the building knew it to be the truth—he then said if Wren did not make it for him, it belonged to Haines—I said, if he dared to take it away, or Haines either, I should lock them up wherever I found them, for stealing the rule, as it was mine—this was in the latter end of May—I was at the building, and observed the rule was missing in July, and I sent to the prisoners, by a boy who they employed to work for them—I sent three different messages—Haines at last came to me on the 7th of August, and brought this rule, it was on a Monday morn
ing, and he seemed as if he had been drinking—he said, "Do you call this rule yours?"—I said, "Yes, certainly I do call it mine"—he said, "You are a d—liar"—he said, "I will tell you how I came by that rule; it belonged to the Asphalte Company "—I said it certainly did not—he said, "Their name is on the rule now"—I said it certainly was not, "E. Byfield" was on it—he said it was not—I turned it up, and said, "There it is"—he said "He had a right to put it on, he and I are partners"—I said, "Where is the Asphalte Company's mark?"—he said if it was properly cleaned it would appear—I said it was not, he persisted in taking it away, and pretended as if he was going to knock me down—I said, "If that is it, I shall not leave you till I give you into custody"—I followed him about a mile, and then gave him into custody—I

saw Byfield some distance off, and game him into cus
tody.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Who it your attorney? A. Iam my own—in the first instance I employed Mr. Cripps, an attorney——he said, "I will help you get the bill"—I cannot exactly say when I first missed the rule from the premises—it was about the latter end of May I saw the mark on it—it was on the premises while the prisoners were working for me-—Haines had worked for me twenty-five years, and they had not left off finally after the rule was gone—I think it might be about two months afterwards that I ceased to employ them, because they had got this piece-work, and they defied me to keep them out of the premises—I had no quarrel with them about leaving my work to go on with other, no further than telling them I should set on other hands—I am sorry to say By field lived rather too near roe—I should not think of prosecuting for this rule, only knowing I was repeatedly robbed before—Byfield lived not above 200 or 300 yards from this building, in Mill-lane, I believe—the house has no number—Haines has lived about Brixton twenty-fire years—Haines called upon me on the 7th of Aug.—I had repeatedly claimed the rule of them before that—I sent three distinct messages that they were not to deceive themselves, provided they did not bring that rule back to the place, I should have them locked up—when I first saw the name on it I claimed it—I did not claim it twenty times—I saw By field, and said to him, "Do not deceive yourself, I shall certainly have you locked up"—he did not say I was a liar—he said he bad nothing to do with it, Haines had got it—I went before a Magistrate, and he said, "I should like to do away with regard to the felony, this might be a mistake of these men"—I cannot say whether any de
position was taken, I think there was—they only heard one witness that I had—the prisoners called two witnesses to prove the rule was not mine—I had three witnesses in Court, bot they only heard one—I did not wish to drive the case for the Magistrate to send it to trial—I wished him to give them repri
mand—he did not discharge them—he laid, "I do not discharge them, I leave it to you to indict them at the Sessions."

Q. Did they immediately afterwards bring an action against you for false imprisonment? A. Yes, but that was only to bounce it over me, that I should not go to the Sessions—the Magistrate said, "You can take the rule, and do as you like"—I said, "No, I won't, they may contend that I altered the rule," and the rule has been in the hands of the policeman ever since—the pri
soners served me with a process—I dare say that was dose to get rid of me—the solicitor came and tried to laugh me out of it.

Q. Did not Haines come to you on the 7th or 8th of August, and say, "Here is the rule, do you mean to say it is yours?" and did not you call him a thief? A. Certainly not—I never said such a word—it was to the same purpose—I do not recollect that he said I should hear of it again—Haines took away the rule in August—I followed him about a mile, then met a policeman, and gave him into custody—he did not ask the policeman permission to go and change his clothes, and to call on By field, bis partner—I saw By field about twenty yards off—I do not know whether he was at work or no, but he came to the gate, and I said, "Policeman, this man has been guilty of the same act as the other, I charge him as well"—I did not say the rule had been made two years ago—I said I knew it by its having a flaw—this is the flaw—(looking at it)—I em
ployed an attorney to find the bill—I do not know that the prisoner! had been told by my attorney that he would take no further steps till they came to surrender—it is no such thing—Mr. Cripps told me he had seen their attorney, and, for honour sake, he would not take them without giving them notice—I waited here all day, and did not say anything further to Mr. Cripps; and, after

standing about here till Tuesday, I said, "I won't stand about here in this way"—I went to Union-ball, and applied for the warrant—I believe that was about four o'clock—the policeman went with me, and the prisoners were locked up that night, I believe, and taken the next day before the Magistrate—he said he had no power—he certainly did not let the prisoners go, be
cause they came to Newgate, and laid here all nights—I appeared before Mr. Justice Erskine last Sessions—he ordered the prisoners to be admitted to bail—on that J asked for my expenses, and he said I should have every farthing—he said I should have them, if this did not turn out to be a vindic
tive prosecution—I certainly never said, that if they would abandon their action I would my prosecution, or any thing of the kind.

MR. CARTISN. Q. Was it the first time you saw the letters on the rule that you spoke to Byfield about it? A. Two or three daya after, the first time I got sight of him—the indictment was found on the Monday in the last Sessions, about twelve or one o'clock—I applied for the warrant on Tuesday, and it was put into my hand about four o'clock—it was executed that night, I believe.

JURY. Q. Did you find the rest of their tools? A. Yes, but I would almost as lief decline answering anything—I bad missed property, and had accused them—we generally find tools, but in this case I was to find every thing, except wax for casting, and the other tools carried in a basket.

DAVID REEVE . I live at Brixton. I have worked for Mr. Cooper—I made this rule, and sent it to the building—I know it—(looking at it)—it is just as it was when I made it—I bad some words about it with Mr. Cooper—I said it would never be fit for a floating-rale—I said it was a very shaky piece, not proper for the purpose—I am sure this is the rule—it is not exactly in the same state, it is a little narrowed at each end—it was straight all along when I gave it to the boy to take down—I made it about twelve months ago last April.

Cross-examined. Q. What is it worth? A. Not a great deal, something under 10s.; I suppose it is worth about 2s. 6d. or 3s.—what I know it by is this flaw, which it shakes with—I described it as not fit for the purpose—I am quite sure I did not swear that I made it three yean ago—I did not all the Magistrate it was three years—I do not know that I said it was two years—it was about twelve months last April.
JURY. Q. Do you know it by anything but the shake? A. No, sir—I can swear to the wood, as being the wood I prepared.

JOHN MILLER . I am a bricklayer. I worked for Mr. Cooper last May—I worked for a short time at the building where the prisoners were at work—I remember, about May, Byfield came there, and Mr. Cooper accused him of stealing the rule—he asked him why he put bis name on the rule—Byfield said it was his—Mr. Cooper said it was not, it was a rule belonging to himself—I do not recollect anything else.

PETER CHARLES . I am a bricklayer. I was at work at Mr. Cooper's buildings in May. I remember Mr. Cooper asking Byfield what business he had to put his name on his rule—Byfield said it was his rule; and he said as far as this, that it was bis intention to take the rule away—Mr. Cooper said, "It is mine, and you may depend, if you take that rule away, I will lock you up"—Byfield said he would insist on taking it George Brydges (police-constable P 128.) I was in Coalharbour-lane on the 7th of August—I saw Haines with this rule, and I took him into custody by Mr. Cooper's direction—I afterwards saw Byfield, and took him—I took both the prisoners to the station—I was at the police-office afterwards—the Magistrate said Mr. Cooper might take his rule.

GEORGE SPIGGET . I am a carpenter. I have been at work for Mr. Cooper—I know this rule—I first saw it last April twelvemonth—I was working for a plasterer then, and fetched the rule for the plasterer from David Reeve's—I have seen it once since—I am able to swear positively to it—it is the same rule.
Cross-examined. Q. You know it by the flaw, I suppose? A. Yes.

HENRY COOPER . I am the prosecutor's son. I remember, on the 7th of August, Haines came to my father's house, and brought this rule—he asked my father whether he meant to say that that rule was his—my father said he should know it amongst a thousand—Haines said it was his, and he would tell him where he got it; when he was at work at a house in Streatham Para
gon, the rule was there, and it belonged to the Asphalte Company, and they left it at the house, and the people of the house gave it up to him; and he said, if it was cleaned, the Asphalte Company's name was on it then, and he could show it him in a minute—he then left with the rule.

WILLIAM ALLEN . I am a bricklayer. I know the two prisoners—I knew Byfield while at work at Brixton-hill, two years ago last March—while he was going off the scaffold I saw his floating-rule fall—he was in the act of shoving the tools on one side of the scaffold—the rule slipped off the scaffold, and I saw this nail driven in it on that occasion—this is the rule—(looking at it)—I say so on account of this mark—it fell on the ground, and this end of it fell against a oil), and made this mark on it—I saw the rule split, and I law him drive this nail into it—I told him the rule was not injured a bit—I could swear to it among ten thousand—I was examined before the Magistrate—I saw the rule chip by the "E. B.," and I saw Byfield drive the nail into it; and seeing it now with this indenture, and this nail, I have not the least doubt it is the same—I have known Byfield four years—his character has been very honourable—I never knew him charged with anything.

MR. CARTEEN. Q. By what do you take on yourself to swear to this rule? A. I have explained it by this being chipped off, touching the "E. B." which is on it—he said when it fell, "D—you, this is all the good you hare done me"—I said, "It has not hurt your rule nor you, but very near knocked your name out"—this was in the middle of last March two years—I had never seen the rule before, to my knowledge—I have seen it since, at Union-hall—I tee it now, and I have seen it at Brixton—I do not know that I can say candidly that I have seen it any other time—I never examined it before the day the accident happened—I examined it at Union-hall, and I hare examined it now—this accident happened to it at Brixton-bill, at Mr. Mugge
ridge's house.

JURY. Q. Did you drive the nail? A. No—Byfield did, and I believe can tell you what the nail is—about two years elapsed between my first seeing the rule and my seeing it again—Byfield called on me, and said, "It is the same rule that you saw fall from the scaffold/' and I remembered that I said, "It has not hurt you, but nearly knocked your name off."
JAMES WAY . I served my time with Mr. Haines. He has lived in Brixton twenty-five years, and was an honest, upright man as ever lived—I never heard him charged with any offence.

MR. CARTEEN. Q. Have you ever worked for Mr. Cooper? A. Yet, I have, when Haines has been there—I never heard Mr. Cooper accuse him of anything—I have brought this rule from Haines's place to Mr. Cooper's home.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When Haines was at work, and Cooper saw it there? A. Yes—he saw me use it there—it was the latter end of April, or the begin
ning of May that I commenced there, I cannot say which—Haines was there.

3108.
PHILIP KNOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of Oct., I bushel of onions, value 2s., the goods of
William Thomas Attwood, his master.

LOT BENNETT . I am in the service of William Thomas Attwood, of Mort
lake. On the 6th of Oct. I saw the prisoner come and put his bands between the plating and the tiles, and take onions out of the loft—he put them into something, and took them into the stable, and put them into his bin—he brought them out one at a time, and put them into the horses' note-bags—these are the onions.

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Confined Three Months.

3109.
MARGARET WESTON and
SARAH CARROLL were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of Oct., 1 coat, value 10s.; the goods of
James Clarke; and 3 brushes, value 10s.; the goods of Henry Hatfield.

JAMES CLARKE . I am a painter. I left Mr. Duckie's premises on the 6th of Oct.—I returned in ten minutes, and found these two prisoners had opened the coach-house door, and got these brushes and coat—I found these three dusting brushes under Western's handkerchief—they are Henry Hatfield's—I had left this coat of mine in the back stable—it waa removed from thence to the coach-house, where I found the prisoners.
CARROLL. I did not have the coat.
(Carroll received a good character.)

WESTON—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

CARROLL—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

3110.
JOSEPH WICKINS was indicted
for embezzlement.

HENRY WITHERS . I keep a brewery at Camberwell-green. The prisoner was in my service as drayman for about two years, up to last May—he had 18s. a week—it was hit duty to receive money on my account—he was to account to me on the same day when he came home, or, if late, it was booked the next day—he did not account to me for 4s. 6d. received from Clark on the 6th of May for a cask of porter, nor for 4s. 6d. received from Mrs. Chandler, about the 23rd of May—I had sent her an account by the prisoner of 1l. 7s.—it was all made out in items of 4s. 6d.—this is it—the first item is At. 6d., he did not account to me for that—the prisoner did not account to me on the 1st of August for St. 6d. received from Mr. or Mrs. Matthews, for a cask of beer.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Tell me the date on which he left your employ? A. On the 2nd of Sept., that was the last day he worked for me—I think it was on the 23rd of Sept. I gave him into custody—he had not gone into the employ of a rival brewer—there is a person of the name of Osman in my neighbourhood—the prisoner told me he was in the employ of Mr. Bailey, a brewer, in Wyndham-road—he did not tell me he should go into the employ of Osman—he has never been three days without accounting—I made the entries in a book which the prisoner saw—I have the whole of my books here—I do not know that he ever kept any book—he had sometimes ten or twenty customers to go to in a day.

Q. In addition to his wages, was he entitled to a certain sum of money in the event of his obtaining new customers? A. No, that has been dropped above twelve months—I used to give him 1s. a customer—I do not owe him any money—when he called at my house, about a fortnight after he left me, he left word that he took 4s. 6d. and got drunk with it—I went down to his wife, and after that he called upon me—he did not say, as I owed him 20s. it

would be all right—he never said at any time that I owed him any money—I did not account with him last Christmas for any money—when I went down to his wife, I said he had been round with Bailey and Osman's cards to solicit my customers—I had had the cards handed to me from the customers when I went round—I think I had told the policeman of this charge before I had been to the prisoner's wife, but the policeman could not catch him—after I found he had taken up the hills, I went to his wife's to see him, and I told her of this, as I considered I had a right to do so—he had been in my service upwards of two years—it might be an hour or two after I went to his wife that he called upon me—he was taken into custody on the 23rd, which was about a week after.

MR. DOANE. Q. When you gave notice to the police, you had not dis
covered these three sums? A. No—I found he had received a great many bills that he is not charged with now, and that was what I went down about—he said he bad taken up three bills, but they are not the bills charged here.

CATHARINE MATTHEWS . I am the wife of William James Matthews, of Eaton-square, Pimlico. On the 1st of Aug. I paid the prisoner 3s. 6d.—this is the bill he brought—he put this receipt to it—it was for the only cask of beer he ever brought me.

CATHARINE CLARK . I am the wife of Joseph Clark, of Jewin-crescent, Aldersgate-street. On the 6th of May I paid the prisoner 4s. 6d.—this is the bill—he wrote this receipt at the bottom—it is for a cask of porter, the only one I had.
MARY ELIZABETH CHANDLER . I am the wife of Matthew Chandler. On the 23rd of May I paid the prisoner 4s. 6d. off this bill of 1l. 7s.

PATRICK DALEY (police-constable P 246.) I received information, and found the prisoner in about two hours—I told him I took him for embezzling various stints of money—he said he believed there was a difference of 4s. 6d.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you known him? A. Yes, about four years, in respectable employ.
NOT GUILTY .

3111.
THOMAS DICKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Oct., 4 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; and 1 stock, 3s.; the goods of
Thomas Brooks and another, his masters.

CHARLES JOHN BROOKS . I superintend the business of my brother, Tho
mas Brooks and another, linen-drapers, High-street, Borough; the prisoner was in their service. On the 7th of October I told him we had reason to suspect he had robbed the firm—he said he had not taken anything belonging to us—I and my brother went with him, and searched his drawers, which were by the door of his room—they are for the use of the young men—they were unlocked then—we found in the drawer his clothes, and amongst them a satin stock, which appeared to have been worn—he then wished us to ter
minate the search, by pushing in the drawer—my brother said, "No, not yet, we must look in your pockets"—we found these four cambric handker chiefs in his coat-pocket—my brother asked if it was his coat, and he said, "Yes"—I know these handkerchiefs, by their having the mark of the firm upon them, and the stock by the private mark—we sent for an officer, and gave him in charge—he might have said something, but I do not recollect it—he was not entitled to purchase things, without having them entered in the book—the books are not here—there is no entry of these—I know they had only been in our stock a week—other persons sell besides me, but they are not here.

Prisoner. On the Saturday before you asked me to go on an errand for you. I asked you to get me some handkerchiefs, and you got me three dozen. I took them on the Sunday, and on the Monday I brought them back, and paid you 13s. 6d. for half a dozen of them. I said I wanted a dozen very good ones, and I told you on Monday they were not good enough. I wanted to go on a week-day, and you said, "Would it not do on Sunday?" I said,"Yes." On the Saturday these things came in; I took four, put them in paper, and put them into my pocket. I believe I told the person to enter them. You knew that the people were friends, and I have had goods before, and paid you. Witness. That was a fortnight before, when he took some handkerchiefs to show to a customer—he had them entered on a memorandum—he brought nine of them back, and the money for the others.

COURT. Q. Could he ever receive goods without their being entered in a book? A. Never—we should give any man in charge if he took them out without—he could not receive them to take out to show a customer without their being entered, because we do not allow it—those that he says he had to show, he had on memorandum, and I knew of it—I believe they were en
tered—I did not see them entered.

Prisoner. Have I not been entrusted to fetch goods from the City, to take to customers, without any entry? did I not fetch a lot of carpets, and take them to Captain Hudson, and other customers? I believe I told them to enter these handkerchiefs down. Witness. I have asked every young man in the establishment, and they say you did not; he was never entrusted to go out with goods from the shop to show, without their being entered—we have three shops—he was only in one shop—if he had teen trusted by any other person in the shop, it would have come to my knowledge—we have only about five young men there.
JOHN COOK (police-sergeant M 8.) I took the prisoner.
Prisoner. He knew I was going to take these handkerchiefs to a particular friend—the stock was paid for—it was bought for me, by a lady, at their other concern.

JURY TO CHARLES J. BROOKS . Q. Were the handkerchiefs in the coat he wore every day? A. No, it was his best coat—they were folded up just at they are in the shop—I do not in general send persons with goods on a Sun
day, only this was a friend of bis, and I said if he was going up, he might take them—the first lot he took with my knowledge was two dozen on the Saturday—he brought part of them back on the Monday, and the money—he might have said they wanted to see others, but I had no knowledge that he meant to take others.
NOT GUILTY .

3112.
ANN LINDFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Sept 1 bed, value 6s.; 1 coal-scuttle, 1s.; 4 towels, 3s.; 2 sheets, 2s.; 2 blan
kets, 2s. 6d.; 2 candlesticks, 1s., 1 pair of bellows, 1s.; 3 carpets. 1s.; 2 saltcellars, 2s.; I tumbler, 1s.; 1 teapot, 1s.; 3 wine glasses, 1s.; 1 look-ing-glass, 1s.; 3 saucepans, 2s. 6d.; 1 frying-pan, 1s.; 1 set of fire-irons, 2s.; 1 spice-box, 6d.; 3 tea trays, 2s. 6d.; 4 cups, 1s.; 4 saucers, 1s.; 12 plates, 6s.; 3 basons, 1s.; 1 pitcher, 1s. 6d.; 3 jugs, it.; 3 dishes, 1s. 6d.; 1 ladle, 6d.; and 1 tureen, 1s.; the goods of
George Gardner, her master.

HARRIET SARAH GARDNER . I am the wife of George Gardner, and live in Walcott-place, Lambeth. The prisoner was in my service—on the after
noon
of the 28th of Sept, I left home, and all my property was safe—on my return I missed the things mentioned—these are them—they are ours.
WILLIAM ETHERIDGE (police-constable L 35.) I took the prisoner at her lodgings, and found a shirt and towel there—she said Mrs. Gardner gave them to her.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me in the room? A. I saw you at the door of the house—I found four duplicates on you, and the things at the pawn
broker's that they relate to.
Prisoner. These things are my own.
MRS. GARDNER re-examined. I am sure they are mine—they are marked with my husband's initials, G. G.
Prisoner. They left me in the house, owing me 30s., and never said they were coming back. I was there two days, and never took anything from them.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

3113.
ANN LINDEORD was again indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of March, 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 table-cloth, 2s.; 1 blanket, 1s. 6d.; and 1 bed
tick, 4s.; the goods of
George Gardner, her master.
HARRIET SARAH GARDNER . I am the wife of George Gardner. Among other things, I missed a table-cloth, blanket, and bed-tick—I have ex amined those that are here, and have no doubt they are ours.
WILLIAM EDWARD VINCENT . I am a pawnbroker. These articles were pawned by the prisoner on the 7th, 9th, and 24th of March.
JOHN ETHERIDGE (policeman.) I produce the duplicates of these things. They were found at the station by the female searcher.

GUILTY . Aged 56.—
Confined Three Months more.

3114.
RICHARD CARTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Sept., 1 jacket, value 3s. 6d.; 1 pair of trowsers, 3s.; and 1 blanket, 3s. 6d.; the goods of
William Pether, his master.
(The prosecutor did not appear.)
NOT GUILTY .

3115.
WILLIAM LLOYD was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. SCRIVEN and DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH KNOWLES . I am the wife of Henry Knowles. The prisoner came on the 30th of August for a pint of porter—he paid me a bad half-crown—I examined it, and put it into the till—there was nothing else in the till but a sixpence and a fourpenny-piece—I afterwards went to the till, took out the half-crown, and showed it to my husband—I then took it up stairs, and put it into a box, which I kept locked—on the 11th of September he came for half a pint of sixpenny ale, and gave me a bad shilling—my husband went after him, but did not find him—I placed the shilling in a cup on the shelf, behind some bottles—he came again on the 16th of Sept., to see if I would let him have half a pint of porter on trust—he said he would come again, and I trusted him—he came in again, about half-past eleven o'clock, and threw down a penny to pay for the porter, then he threw down a bad shilling, and said, "Change, if you please"—I gave the shilling to my son, and told him to fetch a policeman—I told the prisoner my son was gone to get change, and he waited—my son brought Green, an officer, with him—I gave the officer the half-crown and the shilling I had received from the prisoner, and my son gave him the other shilling.

COURT. Q. How was it you did not stop him when he brought the shil
ling?
A. It looked so well, I could not tell it from a good one, when he laid it down, and I had no one there.
HENRY KNOWLES . I am the son of Sarah Knowles. I saw the prisoner come in on the 16th—he put down a shilling on the counter—my mother gave it to me—I went for the constable, and gave it him.
MARK GREEN (police-sergeant L 2.) I took the prisoner on the 16th—I produce the two shillings and the half-crown.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These two shillings and the half-crown are all counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. I never tendered the half-crown; I declare I never gave her the two first pieces; I never was in the house before, and she said, "I consider you are the person who uttered it."

GUILTY .* Aged 43.—
Confined One Year.

3116.
ELIZABETH NUGENT was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Oct., 1 box, value 5s.; 8 sovereigns, 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, 1 10l., and 2 5l. Bank notes, the property of
James Joseph Holland, her master.
JAMES JOSEPH HOLLAND . Iam a dyer, and live in High-street, Newington.

The prisoner was my shopwoman—on the 22nd of Oct. I missed a box from a drawer in my sister's bedroom—there was a 10l. note, two 5l. notes, and—some gold in it, I am not certain how much—I think the box was kept locked—my sister kept the key of it—I do not know when it was safe—on the 24th I received the box from the prisoner—the notes were in it right, and, as far at we know, the gold was right.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANB. Q. Did you say to the prisoner, if she would give you an account of what she knew about this box, you would deal mercifully with her? A. Yes—I do not know so much about this as my sister—I do not live on the premises.
NOT GUILTY .

3117.
JOHN HARWELL was indicted
for obtaining money by false pretences.

HARRIET REED . I am servant to Mr. Henry Gooch, at Camberwell. I received this paper from the collector of the Vauxhall Water-works, for 1l. 11s. 6d. due for water—the prisoner afterwards came—he said he had called for the water-rate—I asked if it was right—he said, "Yes, quite right"—I asked him to give me a receipt, or sign the bill—he said he could not write, bat he would put his cross—I believed he came from the collector, and had a right to come from him, for the rate, and I paid him the money on that belief, and he put his cross to this paper.

HENRY WALLER . I am the superintendant of the Vauxhall Water-works. Our collector is Mr. Benjamin Walmsley—the prisoner had no right whatever to call for this money—he is not connected with the Company.
Prisoner. I did not call for any rate for the water—it is for watering the roads that I have got the contract for.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months.

3118.
ANN RAFTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of Oct., 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign; the monies of
Joshua Ewbanke, from his person.

JOSHUA EWBANKE . I am shopman to Mr. Ashton, of Blackroan-street. On the 2nd of Oct. I had been with some friends, and about half-past twelve o'clock at night I went into a public-house—the prisoner was there, and from fifteen to twenty more men and women—she asked me to treat her to a glass

of ale—I refused—she afterwards asked for oysters—I refused—she kept an
noying me—the landlord said if she did not behave better, he would turn her out—I had three sovereigns and a half and some silver in my pocket—she still annoyed me, and the landlord turned her out, and told me to stop, which I did for a quarter of an hour—I then went out—she was standing against the door alone—she put her hand round me in an indecent manner, and put it into my pocket, which was not buttoned—I pushed her from me, and missed a sovereign and a half—I charged her with the robbery—she knocked at a door, and called Jem—a black man came out and spoke to her—a policeman came along, and I gave her in charge—my money was not found.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. Where had you come from? A. Mr. Deret's rope manufactory—I had supped there-—I had a glass of sherry and water—I drank nothing but water at supper—I only went to this one public-house—I felt my money safe after she was turned out—I said nothing to her when I came oat—she directly took hold of me, and put her hand into my pocket.
COURT. Q. Why not seize her hand? A. She did it so quick—I was quite sober.
JOHN CHEESEMAN (policeman.) I searched the prisoner, but found only 11d. on her.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 27TH OF NOVEMBER.
The following Prisoners, in whose cases Judgment was, at the time of conviction respited, have been sentenced as under:—
John Crawley... Page 79... Confined One Year.
John Dixon... Page... Confined One Year.
George Farmer... " 244... Transported for Fifteen Years.
Samuel Sidney Smith... " 645... Transported for Life.
Matthew Ledger... " 814... Transported for Seven Years.
